It is not designed to infer any political boundaries. The purpose is to provide a consistent overview of European marine extent and for this reason a single tidal extent is selected. This is consistent with IHO-57 definitions

FeatureType.name: MarineExtent
FeatureType.title: Marine Extent
FeatureType.definition: The extent of a sea area for a given tidal state
FeatureType.description: The expected 2D geometric extent of a SeaArea for a particular tidal state.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geometry of the Marine Extent.
FeatureAttribute.description: A GM_MultiSurface is used as at different tidal states, areas of sea may become land-locked and therefore unconnected even though they are still part of the sea. This is primarily a consideration for local scale seas.

FeatureAttribute.name: waterLevel
FeatureAttribute.title: water level
FeatureAttribute.definition: Water level at which the extent is valid.

FeatureType.name: ParameterValuePair
FeatureType.title: Parameter Value Pair
FeatureType.definition: A parameter value pair contains a value of some observed property. e.g. Annual Mean Sea Surface Temperature.

FeatureAttribute.name: parameter
FeatureAttribute.definition: A definition of the observed parameter (e.g. mean temperature).

FeatureAttribute.name: value
FeatureAttribute.definition: the value of the observed parameter, e.g. 12 degrees Celsius.

FeatureAttribute.name: validTime
FeatureAttribute.title: valid time
FeatureAttribute.definition: The time for which the attributed value is valid. This may be a time instant or a duration.

FeatureType.name: MarineIsoline
FeatureType.title: Marine Isoline
FeatureType.definition: An isoline representing a particular value of some marine physical or chemical phenomenon such as temperature, salinity or wave height.
FeatureType.description: A Marine Contour representing a particular value of some phenomenon. The geometry of the contour is a GM_Multicurve, i.e. may be formulated from several curves, all representing the same value e.g. 15 degrees celsius.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.title: Geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: Geometry of the isolines.

FeatureAttribute.name: value
FeatureAttribute.title:
Value
-
FeatureAttribute.definition: Values attributed to the isolines.

FeatureType.name: MarineCirculationZone
FeatureType.title: Marine Circulation Zone
FeatureType.definition: A sea area defined by its physical and chemical circulation patterns.
FeatureType.description: Typically used for management and reporting of the marine environment or marine environmental classification.

FeatureAttribute.name: zoneType
FeatureAttribute.title: Zone Type
FeatureAttribute.definition: The type of the Marine Circulation Zone, e.g. sedimentCell.

FeatureAttribute.name: extent
FeatureAttribute.definition: The extent of the Marine Circulation Zone at a particular tidal state
Extent of the Marine Circulation Zone.

FeatureType.name: Sea
FeatureType.definition: Extent of sea at High Water (meanHighWater).
FeatureType.description: An area of sea, bounded by land and adjacent sea regions. May contain smaller scale sea regions. Has common large scale circulation patterns, in part defined by its land boundaries. High Water is taken to be mean high water. Applies to common names areas of sea, e.g. North Sea, Agean Sea etc. (Source: IHO S23 SeaRegion)

FeatureAttribute.name: extent
FeatureAttribute.definition: The extent of the Sea at Mean High Water

FeatureType.name: SewerPipe
FeatureType.title: sewer pipe
FeatureType.definition: A sewer pipe used to convey wastewater (sewer) from one location to another.

FeatureAttribute.name: sewerWaterType
FeatureAttribute.title: sewer water type
FeatureAttribute.definition: Type of sewer water.

FeatureType.name: DerivedSoilProfile
FeatureType.title: derived soil profile
FeatureType.definition: non-point-located soil profile that serves as a reference profile for a specific soil type in a certain geographical area.
FeatureType.description: The characteristics of a derived soil profile are mostly derived (e.g. averaged) from one or several observed profiles of the same soil type in the area of interest, or are designed with expert knowledge about the same kind of landscape.
NOTE 1 The derived soil profile represents the average or typical profile that characterizes the so called soil typological unit, soil series.

RelationshipRole.name: isDerivedFrom
RelationshipRole.definition: link to one or more observed soil profiles from which this profile has been derived.
RelationshipRole.description: A derived soil profile can be derived from one to many observed soil profiles. If no observed profiles are provided or have been used to produce the derivedSoilProfile, this association can be left empty.

RelationshipRole.name: role_T31509
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: OtherHorizonNotationType
FeatureType.title: other horizon notation type
FeatureType.definition: classification of a horizon according to a specific classification system.
FeatureType.description: A code system denoting horizons in which the same dominant soil forming processes have been active in the same way. This code summarizes many observations of the soil description and gives an impression about the genetic processes that have formed the soil under observation.

FeatureAttribute.name: horizonNotation
FeatureAttribute.title: horizon notation
FeatureAttribute.definition: notation characterizing the soil horizon according to a specified classification system.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE This is also called horizon designation value, horizon designation or horizon symbol.
EXAMPLE “ss” connotes slickensides in Soil taxonomy (FAO uses “I” for this).
The notation in several classification systems can be the same as well: “Ap” is a A horizon which has been ploughed (according German Bodenkundliche Kartieranleitung, 5th ed).

FeatureAttribute.name: isOriginalClassification
FeatureAttribute.title: is original classification
FeatureAttribute.definition: Boolean value to indicate whether the specified horizon notation system was the original notation system to describe the horizon.
FeatureAttribute.description: This is to indicate whether the horizon notation has been determined in the field (or for derived soil profiles during the original derivation), or has been adapted, changed or assigned on the basis of the original horizon description later. This might be relevant for data quality information.

FeatureType.name: ObservedSoilProfile
FeatureType.title: observed soil profile
FeatureType.definition: a representation of a soil profile found on a specific location which is described on the basis of observations in a trial pit or with a borehole.
FeatureType.description: The observed soil profile corresponds to a set of data taken directly from a georeferenced soil profile, described in the field, and often sampled and analyzed in the laboratory.

RelationshipRole.name: location
RelationshipRole.definition: the location of an observed profile is the soilplot.

RelationshipRole.name: observedProfile
RelationshipRole.definition: Link to the observed soil profile for which the soil plot provides location information.
RelationshipRole.description: the soil plot is the location at which the profile has been observed.

FeatureType.name: ParticleSizeFractionType
FeatureType.title: particle size fraction type
FeatureType.definition: share of the soil that is composed of mineral soil particles of the size within the size range specified.
FeatureType.description: Mineral part of the soil, fractioned on the basis of size (diameter), limits of the particles. It is the fine earth fraction. That is, the portion of the soil that passes through a 2 mm diameter sieve opening.
The grain (or particle) size distribution characterizes the soil mineral material, based on the share of each equivalent diameter class of the individual particles.
SOURCE1 NRCS Natural Resources Conservation Service, Soil survey laboratory information manual, Soil survey investigation report n.45 version 1.0 May 1995 pag. 11
SOURCE2 GLOSSARY OF SOIL SCIENCE TERMS

FeatureAttribute.name: fractionContent
FeatureAttribute.title: fraction content
FeatureAttribute.definition: Percentage of the defined fraction.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE NRCS Natural Resources Conservation Service, Soil survey laboratory information manual, Soil survey investigation report n.45 version 1.0 May 1995 pag. 11
NOTE sum of the percentages of all the fractions should be equal to 100 percentage
EXAMPLE percentage value (weight/weight)

FeatureAttribute.name: fractionParticleSizeRange
FeatureAttribute.title: fraction particle size range
FeatureAttribute.definition: upper and lower limit of the particle size of the defined fraction (expressed in µm)
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE NRCS Natural Resources Conservation Service, Soil survey laboratory information manual, Soil survey investigation report n.45 version 1.0 May 1995 pag. 11
EXAMPLE upper limit = 63µm , lower limit =20µm

FeatureType.name: SoilThemeCoverage
FeatureType.title: soil theme coverage
FeatureType.definition: a spatial object type that holds values for a property based on one or more soil and possibly non soil parameters within its spatial, temporal or spatiotemporal domain.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE Adapted from "Coverage" [ISO 19123:2005].

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin life span version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end life span version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: domainExtent
FeatureAttribute.title: Domain extent.
FeatureAttribute.definition: The attribute domainExtent shall contain the extent of the spatiotemporal domain of the coverage. The data type EX_Extent, is defined in ISO 19103. Extents may be specified in both space and time.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE Adapted from [ISO 19123:2005].

FeatureAttribute.name: validTimeFrom
FeatureAttribute.title: valid time from
FeatureAttribute.definition: The ValidTime specifies the time window for which measurements have been captured to calculate the thematic soil property relevant for that period. The start time defines when the period began.

FeatureAttribute.name: validTimeTo
FeatureAttribute.title: valid time to
FeatureAttribute.definition: The ValidTime specifies the time window for which measurements have been captured to calculate the thematic soil property relevant for that period. The end time defines when the period stopped.

FeatureAttribute.name: soilThemeParameter
FeatureAttribute.title: soil theme parameter
FeatureAttribute.definition: A soil-related property (soil theme) that is represented by this coverage.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE Land irrigation suitability, pH in the topsoil, etc

RelationshipRole.name: isDescribedBy
RelationshipRole.definition: this association allows for a certain SoilThemeCoverage to have a related Coverage which does not have a meaning without the base coverage.
RelationshipRole.description: EXAMPLE a coverage of the pH of the topsoil is associated with a coverage with exactly the same extent and domain reporting on the level of confidence of the pH values of the base coverage.

RelationshipRole.name: isDescribing
RelationshipRole.definition: this association allows for a certain SoilThemeCoverage to have a related Coverage which does not have a meaning without the base coverage.
RelationshipRole.description: EXAMPLE a coverage of the pH of the topsoil is associated with a coverage with exactly the same extent and domain reporting on the level of confidence of the pH values of the base coverage.

FeatureType.name: RangeType
FeatureType.title: range type
FeatureType.definition: A range value defined by an upper limit and a lower limit.

FeatureAttribute.name: upperValue
FeatureAttribute.title: upper value
FeatureAttribute.definition: value defining the upper limit of a specific property.

FeatureAttribute.name: lowerValue
FeatureAttribute.title: lower value
FeatureAttribute.definition: value defining the lower limit of a specific property.

FeatureAttribute.name: uom
FeatureAttribute.title: unit of measure
FeatureAttribute.definition: The unit of measure that is used to express the values of the range.

FeatureType.name: DerivedProfilePresenceInSoilBody
FeatureType.title: derived profile presence in soil body
FeatureType.definition: indicates the percentages (lower and upper boundary) that the derived profile takes part in the Soil body.
FeatureType.description: NOTE 1 A soil body is characterized by one or more derived soil profiles in a defined geographic area. When the soil body is characterized by more than one derived profiles, the distribution area of these derived soil profiles is not spatially defined, but their presence is indicated by a range of percentages.
NOTE 2 The sum of lower boundary parts should not exceed 100%.
NOTE 3 If not a range, but a specific percentage is used then the lower and upper boundaries are equal.

FeatureAttribute.name: derivedProfilePercentageRange
FeatureAttribute.title: derived profile percentage range.
FeatureAttribute.definition: Interval that defines the minimum and maximum percentage of the area of the soil body represented by a specific derived soil profile.

FeatureType.name: ProfileElement
FeatureType.title: profile element
FeatureType.definition: An abstract spatial object type grouping soil layers and / or horizons for functional/operational aims.
FeatureType.description: Profile element is the general term for both horizons and layers.
This type is abstract.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire Id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the profile element.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: particleSizeFraction
FeatureAttribute.title: particle size fraction
FeatureAttribute.definition: Mineral part of the soil, fractioned on the basis of size (diameter), limits of the particles. It indicates how much of the mineral soil material is composed of soil particles of the specified size range.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE NRCS Natural Resources Conservation Service, Soil survey laboratory information manual, Soil survey investigation report n.45 version 1.0 May 1995 pag. 11

FeatureAttribute.name: profileElementDepthRange
FeatureAttribute.title: profile element depth range
FeatureAttribute.definition: Upper and lower depth of the profile element (layer or horizon) measured from the surface (0 cm) of a soil profile (in cm).
FeatureAttribute.description: Depth range consists of the average upper and lower depth of appearance of the profile element from the surface.

NOTE Most soil boundaries are zones of transition rather than sharp lines of division. The average depth of the upper boundaries and the average depth of the lower boundaries of each profile element are given in centimetres, measured from the surface (including organic and mineral covers) of the soil downwards, i.e. all depth values are positive numbers.
EXAMPLE H horizon 0-5 cm, A horizon 5-30 cm, B horizon 30-80 cm
NOTE Following rules should be taken into account
<ul>
• lowerValue and upperValue: should be positive values,
• upperValue is the depth from the top of the element (e.g. 20)
• lowerValue is the depth of the bottom of the element (e.g. 40)
• if only upperValue is indicated: it is assumed that the lowerValue is unknown; this is only possible for the deepest layer or horizon of a profile.
• if only lowerValue is indicated: it is assumed that the upperValue equals 0, and thus the range is between 0 and the lowerValue value

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

RelationshipRole.name: isPartOf
RelationshipRole.definition: link to the soil profile which the profile element constitutes.

RelationshipRole.name: isDescribedBy
RelationshipRole.definition: the profile elements (layers and/or horizons) constituting the soil profile.
RelationshipRole.description: A profile element is always part of a soil profile.

FeatureType.name: WRBSoilNameType
FeatureType.title: WRB soil name type
FeatureType.definition: an identification of the soil profile according to the profile to according to “World Reference Base for Soil Resources 2006, first update 2007”, World Soil Resources Reports No. 103. FAO, Rome.
FeatureType.description: NOTE The structure of the WRBSoilNameType was based on the World reference base for soil resources 2006, first update 2007, World Soil Resources Reports No. 103, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United
Nations, Rome, 2007.
EXAMPLE Lixic Vertic Ferralsol (Ferric, Rhodic), WRB 2006, update 2007.

FeatureAttribute.name: WRBQualifierGroup
FeatureAttribute.title: WRB qualifier group
FeatureAttribute.definition: data type to define the a group of a qualifier and its possible specifier(s), its place and position with regard to the WRBReferenceSoilGroup it belongs to.

FeatureAttribute.name: WRBReferenceSoilGroup
FeatureAttribute.title: WRB reference soilgroup (RSG)
FeatureAttribute.definition: first level of classification of the World Reference Base for Soil Resources.
FeatureAttribute.description: Reference Soil Groups are distinguished by the presence (or absence) of specific diagnostic horizons, properties and/or materials.
NOTE The WRB soil classification system comprises 32 different RSGs.
SOURCE World reference base for soil resources 2006, first update 2007, World Soil Resources Reports No. 103, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2007.

FeatureAttribute.name: isOriginalClassification
FeatureAttribute.title: is original classification
FeatureAttribute.definition: Boolean value to indicate whether the WRB classification system was the original classification system to describe the soil profile.
FeatureAttribute.description: This is to indicate whether the soil assignation according to WRB has been determined in the field (or for - derived - profiles during the original derivation process), or has been adapted, changed or re-assigned on the basis of the original soil description or assignation later. This might be relevant data quality information.

RelationshipRole.name: over
RelationshipRole.definition: An association to indicate that in the WRB classification a soil profile covers another developed, older soil.

RelationshipRole.name: role_T31507
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: WRBQualifierGroupType
FeatureType.title: WRB qualifier group type
FeatureType.definition: A data type to define the group of a qualifier and its possible specifier(s), its place and position with regard to the World Reference Base (WRB) Reference Soil Group (RSG) it belongs to according to World reference base for soil resources 2006, first update 2007, World Soil Resources Reports No. 103, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2007.

FeatureAttribute.name: qualifierPlace
FeatureAttribute.title: qualifier place
FeatureAttribute.definition: attribute to indicate the placement of the Qualifier with regard to the WRB reference soil group (RSG). The placement can be in front of the RSG i.e. 'prefix' or it can be behind the RSG i.e. 'suffix'.

FeatureAttribute.name: qualifierPosition
FeatureAttribute.title: qualifier position
FeatureAttribute.definition: number to indicate the position of a qualifier with regard to the WRB reference soil group (RSG) it belongs to and with regard to its placement to that (RSG) i.e. as a prefix or a suffix.
FeatureAttribute.description: If there are one or more prefix qualifiers: one of the qualifiers is in position 1, the other qualifiers are in position 2, 3, etc.; position 1 is the position closest to the RSG; position 2 is the position second closest to the RSG; etc

If there are one or more suffix qualifiers: one of the qualifiers is in position 1, the other qualifiers are in position 2, 3, etc.; position 1 is the position closest to the RSG; position 2 is the position second closest to the RSG; etc

FeatureAttribute.name: WRBqualifier
FeatureAttribute.title: WRB qualifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: name element of WRB, 2nd level of classification
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE World reference base for soil resources 2006, first update 2007, World Soil Resources Reports No. 103, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2007.

FeatureAttribute.name: WRBspecifier
FeatureAttribute.title: WRB specifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: code that indicates the degree of expression of a qualifier or the depth range of which the qualifier applies.
FeatureAttribute.description: Specifiers may be used to indicate depth of occurrence, or to express the intensity of soil characteristics.
EXAMPLE Buried layers can be indicated by the specifier “Thapto”.
NOTE 1 The specifier code is always added after the qualifier code. Exceptions are defined in the qualifier list of WRB.
NOTE 2 Some specifiers can be combined with each other for one qualifier.
SOURCE World reference base for soil resources 2006, first update 2007, World Soil Resources Reports No. 103, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2007.

FeatureType.name: SoilThemeDescriptiveCoverage
FeatureType.title: soil theme descriptive coverage
FeatureType.definition: a spatial object type that is associated to the soil theme coverage and holds additional information on values of a property of the soil theme coverage.
FeatureType.description: This coverage can only exist in relation to a base coverage SoilThemeCoverage, it has the same domain and spatial extent as the base coverage. And it gives extra information on the values of the base coverages
SOURCE Adapted from "Coverage" [ISO 19123:2005].
EXAMPLE coverage indicating the confidence level of the pH values reported in the associated SoilThemeCoverage.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin life span version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end life span version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: domainExtent
FeatureAttribute.title: Domain extent.
FeatureAttribute.definition: The attribute domainExtent shall contain the extent of the spatiotemporal domain of the coverage. The data type EX_Extent, is defined in ISO 19103. Extents may be specified in both space and time.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE Adapted from [ISO 19123:2005].

FeatureAttribute.name: soilThemeDescriptiveParameter
FeatureAttribute.title: soil theme descriptive parameter
FeatureAttribute.definition: a descriptive property for the soil-related property (soil theme) that is represented by its associated SoilThemeCoverage.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE confidence level for each value in the SoilThemeCoverage (pH in the topsoil)

FeatureType.name: SoilHorizon
FeatureType.title: soil horizon
FeatureType.definition: Domain of a soil with a certain vertical extension, more or less parallel to the surface and homogeneous for most morphological and analytical characteristics, developed in a parent material layer through pedogenic processes or made up of in-situ sedimented organic residues of up-growing plants (peat).
FeatureType.description: SOURCE ISO/WD 28258, modified
NOTE Horizons may be part of a layer.

FeatureAttribute.name: FAOHorizonNotation
FeatureAttribute.title: FAO horizon notation
FeatureAttribute.definition: designation of the soil horizon.
FeatureAttribute.description: The FAO horizon notation is a code system characterizing horizons regarding the dominant soil forming processes that have been active during the horizon formation. This code summarizes many observations of the soil description and gives an impression about the genetic processes that have formed the soil under observation.
NOTE The horizon notation is a combination of several letter, number and symbols.
SOURCE Guidelines for soil description, 4<sup>th</sup> edition, Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006
EXAMPLE Bw: meaning B horizon with a development of colour and/or structure.

FeatureAttribute.name: otherHorizonNotation
FeatureAttribute.title: other horizon notation
FeatureAttribute.definition: designation of the soil horizon according to a specific classification system.
FeatureAttribute.description: A code system characterizing horizons regarding the dominant soil forming processes that have been active during the horizon formation. This code summarizes many observations of the soil description and gives information about the genetic processes that have formed the soil under observation.

FeatureType.name: SoilThemeDescriptiveParameterType
FeatureType.title: soil theme descriptive parameter type
FeatureType.definition: data type providing a descriptive property for the soil-related property (soil theme) that is represented by its associated SoilThemeCoverage.
FeatureType.description: this datatype exists of a name and if needed a unit of measurement.
EXAMPLE confidence level for each value in the SoilThemeCoverage (pH in the topsoil)

FeatureAttribute.name: soilThemeDescriptiveParameterName
FeatureAttribute.title: soil theme descriptive parameter name
FeatureAttribute.definition: Name of the parameter to provide extra information on the values of the related SoilThemeCoverage.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE soilThemeDescriptiveParameterName = confidence level. SoilThemeCoverage = coverage representing the pH of the topsoil

FeatureAttribute.name: uom
FeatureAttribute.title: unit of measure
FeatureAttribute.definition: the unit of measure that is used to express the soilThemeDescriptiveParameter.

FeatureType.name: SoilSite
FeatureType.title: soil site
FeatureType.definition: area within a larger survey, study or monitored area, where a specific soil investigation is carried out.
FeatureType.description: Site provides the object to describe:
a.) the surroundings of the plot
and/or

b.) the larger piece of land that is directly linked to and described by all soil investigations on its one or more spots (SoilPlots). It thus provides the object to which soil data of different kind (or the same kind, but at different points in time, e.g. in soil monitoring) obtained on different plots is related as if it would have been collected at the very same place. This allows for:
1. combination of data that cannot be obtained on the very same place

EXAMPLE: a soil pit and investigations on earthworm abundance cannot be done in the same place, but possibly some metres apart from each other. Nonetheless shall the results of both investigations be combined to inform about the soil state.
or
2. comparison of soil condition after some time has elapsed.

EXAMPLE: Organic carbon stock has been investigated using data from two monitoring periods that had to be conducted on spatially slightly separated places because the sampling is destructive. Nonetheless are the results of both periods regarded as giving an idea how organic carbon stock has changed over the years at the same place.
The site is also the object to state the date and time information on validity, etc.

The soil site might have delineation, but can be located with a centre or reference point location only. Delineated soil sites - possibly in the form of cadastral parcels - are especially used in the inventory of contaminated areas.
NOTE Any plot can be linked to one specific site only, but several plots to one site.
SOURCE GS Soil, modified

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire Id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the soil site.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geometry defining the soil site.
FeatureAttribute.description: This can be a polygon defining an area in which the survey was conducted, but it can also be a point location which is used as reference point according to which the soil plots are determined.

FeatureAttribute.name: soilInvestigationPurpose
FeatureAttribute.title: soil investigation purpose
FeatureAttribute.definition: indication why a survey was conducted.
FeatureAttribute.description: For soil two main purposes are identified to carry out soil surveys. One is to classify the soil as a result of soil forming processes (generalSurvey) and the other one is to investigate soil for a specific reason (specificSurvey) like a possible contamination as a result of contaminating activities. This information gives the data user an idea about possible bias in the selection of the site and therefore representativeness of the data that were obtained for a special purpose.

FeatureAttribute.name: validFrom
FeatureAttribute.title: valid from
FeatureAttribute.definition: The time when the phenomenon started to exist in the real world.

FeatureAttribute.name: validTo
FeatureAttribute.title: valid to
FeatureAttribute.definition: The time from which the phenomenon no longer exists in the real world.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

RelationshipRole.name: isObservedOnLocation
RelationshipRole.definition: link to a location(s) where the soil site has been investigated.
RelationshipRole.description: A soil site with a specific investigation purpose can be observed on several locations (soil plots) inside that site area. If only a centre point location is provided, the set of links to soil plots state that the information from these plots can be combined in a meaningful way, i.e. the combination is valid.

RelationshipRole.name: locatedOn
RelationshipRole.definition: link to the soil site on which the soil plot is located or to which the soil plot is belonging.
RelationshipRole.description: a soil plot (location of a soil observation) is located on maximum 1 soil site.

FeatureType.name: SoilBody
FeatureType.title: soil body
FeatureType.definition: Part of the soil cover that is delineated and that is homogeneous with regard to certain soil properties and/or spatial patterns.
FeatureType.description: The soils present in the soil body are characterized by one or more derived soil profiles that are found together in the area specified by the “geometry” attribute of the SoilBody.

NOTE 1 If several derived soil profiles are used to describe the soil body, the spatial distribution of the soil they describe within the soil body is not defined, but their presence is indicated by a range percentage of area. The underlying reason behind the fact of not delineating the different soils within a soil body is the target scale of the map or spatial dataset. This means that geographical accuracy and preciseness of soil characterization depend on and vary with the target scale, i.e. the soil body can be delineated differently among scales.
NOTE 2 The concept of soil body is a correlate of the concept soil mapping unit, and the soils of a soilbody might form e.g. a soil association, a soil complex, etc.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire Id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the soil body.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geometry defining the boundary of the Soil Body.

FeatureAttribute.name: soilBodyLabel
FeatureAttribute.title: soil body label
FeatureAttribute.definition: Label to identify the soil body according to the specified reference framework (metadata).
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE in traditional soil maps, this is the identifier for the explanatory text of the mapping unit of the legend.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

RelationshipRole.name: isDescribedBy
RelationshipRole.definition: Link to a derived soil profile that characterizes the soil body, possibly in combination with other derived soil profiles.
The association has additional properties as defined in the association class DerivedProfilePresenceInSoilBody.
RelationshipRole.description: This association constitutes the link to those derived soil profiles that inform about the internal structure and properties of the soil body.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31515
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: SoilDerivedObject
FeatureType.title: soil derived object
FeatureType.definition: A spatial object type for representing spatial objects with soil-related property derived from one or more soil and possibly other non soil properties.
FeatureType.description: NOTE Soil thematic maps can be derived directly from the involved soil database (organic matter content, pH, texture, etc.) or they can be derived by using pedotransfer functions or pedotransfer rules (e.g. plant available water in the rooting depth). Derivation can be simple extraction from a single data field, or a complex combination of different kind of data and application of e.g. mathematical or expert knowledge-based procedures.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire Id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the SoilDerivedObject.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: the geometry defining the soil derived object.
FeatureAttribute.description: A spatial representation of soil information becomes spatially explicit by delineating areas with similar values according to the soil (or other) property that is represented.

RelationshipRole.name: isBasedOnObservedSoilProfile
RelationshipRole.definition: Link to an observed soil profile on whose properties the derived value is based.
RelationshipRole.description: A soil derived object can be created based on the soil properties of one or more observed soil profiles. If this information shall not be included or does not apply, the association can be empty.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31510
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

RelationshipRole.name: isBasedOnSoilDerivedObject
RelationshipRole.definition: Link to a soil derived object on whose properties the derived value is based.
RelationshipRole.description: A soil derived object can be created based on the properties of one or more other soil derived objects. If this information shall not be included or does not apply, the association can be empty.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31506
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

RelationshipRole.name: isBasedOnSoilBody
RelationshipRole.definition: Link to a soil body on whose properties the derived value is based.
RelationshipRole.description: A soil derived object can be created based on the soil properties of one or more soil bodies. If this information shall not be included or does not apply, the association can be empty.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31514
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: SoilPlot
FeatureType.title: soil plot
FeatureType.definition: spot where a specific soil investigation is carried out.
FeatureType.description: NOTE 1: For observed soil profiles, a spot location has to be defined. It is the place on which the observation is made. The profile is an observation made on the plot.
NOTE 2: All types of plots only provide locality, but no soil information itself.
EXAMPLE A borehole is the location where you gather the information to abstract a profile information from.
SOURCE GS Soil

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire Id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the soil plot.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: soilPlotLocation
FeatureAttribute.title: soil plot location
FeatureAttribute.definition: a reference to a location on the earth; it can be a point location identified by coordinates or a description of the location using text or an identifier.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE reference to a place name, municipality or reference to an exact X,Y location

FeatureAttribute.name: soilPlotType
FeatureAttribute.title: soil plot type
FeatureAttribute.definition: gives information on what kind of plot the observation of the soil is made on.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE Trial pits, boreholes or samples can be seen as types of soil plots.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

FeatureType.name: OtherSoilNameType
FeatureType.title: other soil name type
FeatureType.definition: an identification of the soil profile according to a specific classification scheme.
FeatureType.description: EXAMPLE Fluventic Haploxerept, according to Soil Taxonomy (USDA 2006).

FeatureAttribute.name: soilName
FeatureAttribute.title: soil name
FeatureAttribute.definition: name of the soil profile according to a specific classification scheme.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE Fluventic Haploxerept, according to Soil Taxonomy (USDA 2006).

FeatureAttribute.name: isOriginalClassification
FeatureAttribute.title: is original classification
FeatureAttribute.definition: Boolean value to indicate whether the specified classification scheme was the original classification scheme to describe the profile.
FeatureAttribute.description: This is to indicate whether the soil assignation has been determined in the field (or for - derived soil profiles during the original derivation process), or has been adapted, changed or re-assigned on the basis of the original soil description or assignation later. This might be relevant for data quality information.

FeatureType.name: SoilProfile
FeatureType.title: soil profile
FeatureType.definition: description of the soil that is characterized by a vertical succession of profile elements.
FeatureType.description: NOTE The soil profile is abstracted from observations in a trial pit or a boring, or derived from expert knowledge using other soil profiles.
This type is abstract.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire Id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the soil profile.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: localIdentifier
FeatureAttribute.title: local identifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: unique identifier of the soil profile given by the data provider of the dataset.

FeatureAttribute.name: WRBSoilName
FeatureAttribute.title: WRB soil name
FeatureAttribute.definition: identification of the soil profile.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE The structure of the WRBSoilNameType was based on the World reference base for soil resources 2006, first update 2007. World Soil Resources Reports no 103. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome 2007.
EXAMPLE Lixic Vertic Ferralsol (Ferric, Rhodic); WRB version 2006 (update 2007) or 2010.

FeatureAttribute.name: otherSoilName
FeatureAttribute.title: other soil name
FeatureAttribute.definition: Identification of the soil profile according to a specific classification scheme.

FeatureAttribute.name: validFrom
FeatureAttribute.title: valid from
FeatureAttribute.definition: The time when the phenomenon started to exist in the real world.

FeatureAttribute.name: validTo
FeatureAttribute.title: valid to
FeatureAttribute.definition: The time from which the phenomenon no longer exists in the real world.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: end lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

FeatureType.name: SoilThemeParameterType
FeatureType.title: soil theme parameter type
FeatureType.definition: A soil-related property (soil theme) that is represented by this coverage. It is composed of a parameter name coming from a codelist SoilDerivedObjectParameterNameValue and a Unit of Measure used for expressing that parameter.
FeatureType.description: EXAMPLE Land irrigation suitability, pH in the topsoil, etc

FeatureAttribute.name: soilThemeParameterName
FeatureAttribute.title: soil theme parameter name
FeatureAttribute.definition: name of the parameter represented by the soilThemeCoverage.

FeatureAttribute.name: uom
FeatureAttribute.title: unit of measure
FeatureAttribute.definition: the unit of measure that is used to express the soilThemeParameter.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE cm to express the soilThemeParameter "depth of the B-horizon"

FeatureType.name: FAOHorizonNotationType
FeatureType.title: FAO horizon notation type
FeatureType.definition: A classification of a horizon according to the Horizon classification system specified in Guidelines for soil description, 4th edition, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006.
FeatureType.description: A code system that denotes horizons in which the same dominant soil forming processes has been active similarly. This code summarizes many observations of the soil description and gives an impression about the genetic processes that have formed the soil under observation.
NOTE The horizon notation according to FAO (2006) is a combination of several symbols:
· A number that gives information about discontinuities, i.e. the number of the material in which the soil has formed, counted up from the soil surface, but not for the first material.
· One or two capital letters that designate the type of master horizon (or transitional horizon), possibly separated by a slash
· Lower case letters that designate subordinate characteristics of the horizon.
· A number that designates horizontal subdivisions of otherwise similarly denoted horizon parts
· A prime that enables to distinguish two horizons that have the same naming, but formed in different cycles of pedogenesis.
EXAMPLE 2B' tg1
SOURCE 1 Page 67 - 77 of the Guidelines for soil description, 4th edition, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006. (ISBN 92-5-105521-1)

FeatureAttribute.name: FAOHorizonDiscontinuity
FeatureAttribute.title: FAO horizon discontinuity
FeatureAttribute.definition: number used to indicate a discontinuity in the horizon notation.
FeatureAttribute.description: In mineral soils, Arabic numerals are used as prefixes to indicate discontinuities. Wherever needed, they are used preceding A, E, B, C and R. They are not used with I and W, although these symbols clearly indicate a discontinuity. These prefixes are distinct from Arabic numerals used as suffixes to denote vertical subdivisions.

A discontinuity is a significant change in particle-size distribution or mineralogy that indicates a difference in the material from which the horizons formed or a significant difference in age or both, unless that difference in age is indicated by the suffix b. Symbols to identify discontinuities are used only when they will contribute substantially to the reader’s understanding of relationships among horizons. The stratification common in soils formed in alluvium is not designated as discontinuities unless particle-size distribution differs markedly from layer to layer even though genetic horizons have formed in the contrasting layers.

Where a soil has formed entirely in one kind of material, a prefix is omitted from the symbol; the whole profile is material 1. Similarly, the uppermost material in a profile having two or more contrasting materials is understood to be material 1, but the number is omitted. Numbering starts with the second layer of contrasting material, which is designated 2. Underlying contrasting layers are numbered consecutively.
SOURCE: Guidelines for soil description, 4th edition, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006.
NOTE a discontinuity is a boundary between two geogenic layers.

FeatureAttribute.name: FAOHorizonMaster
FeatureAttribute.title: FAO horizon master
FeatureAttribute.definition: symbol of the master part of the horizon notation.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE Guidelines for soil description (4th ed.) FAO 2006 p. 67

FeatureAttribute.name: FAOPrime
FeatureAttribute.title: FAO prime
FeatureAttribute.definition: A prime and double prime may be used to connotate master horizon symbol of the lower of two respectively three horizons having identical Arabic-numeral prefixes and letter combinations.
FeatureAttribute.description: Identical designations may be appropriate for two or more horizons or layers separated by at least one horizon or layer of a different kind in the same pedon. The sequence A-E-Bt-E-Btx-C is an example - the soil has two E horizons. To make communication easier, a prime is used with the master horizon symbol of the lower of two horizons having identical letter designations: A-E-Bt-E’-Btx-C.The prime is applied to the capital letter designation, and any lower case symbol follows it: B’t. The prime is not used unless all letters of the designations of two different layers are identical. Prime can be used for both minerals or organic soils.
SOURCE: Guidelines for soil description, 4th edition, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006.

FeatureAttribute.name: FAOHorizonSubordinate
FeatureAttribute.title: horizon subordinate
FeatureAttribute.definition: Designations of subordinate distinctions and features within the master horizons and layers are based on profile characteristics observable in the field and are applied during the description of the soil at the site.
FeatureAttribute.description: Lower case letters are used as suffixes to designate specific kinds of master horizons and layers, and other features.
SOURCE Guidelines for soil description, 4th edition, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006. table 85

FeatureAttribute.name: FAOHorizonVertical
FeatureAttribute.title: horizon vertical
FeatureAttribute.definition: Order number of the vertical subdivision in the horizon notation.
FeatureAttribute.description: The number is used to designate the horizontal subdivision of a horizon identified by a single set of letter symbol on the basis of structure, texture, colour, etc.
The number 1 is used to designate the upper part of the horizon. The number 2 the part of the horizon situated below, etc. If there is no horizontal subdivision made, no number is given.

NOTE the use of the word vertical is misleading in the Guidelines for soil description, 4th edition, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, 2006., because the horizons are separated in two or several horizontal subdomains. Vertical denotes the order in vertical direction.

FeatureAttribute.name: isOriginalClassification
FeatureAttribute.title: is original classification
FeatureAttribute.definition: Boolean value to indicate whether the FAO horizon notation was the original notation to describe the horizon.
FeatureAttribute.description: This is to indicate whether the horizon notation has been determined in the field (or for derived profiles during the original derivation), or has been adapted, changed or assigned on the basis of the original horizon description later. This might be relevant data quality information.

FeatureType.name: SoilLayer
FeatureType.title: Soil layer
FeatureType.definition: domain of a soil with a certain vertical extension developed through non-pedogenic processes, displaying a change in structure and/or composition to possibly over- or underlying adjacent domains, or a grouping of soil horizons or other sub-domains with a special purpose.
FeatureType.description: NOTE1 Different kinds of layer concepts are covered by this definition.
EXAMPLE 1 Geogenic layers: These are domains, resulting from e.g. sedimentation (as non-pedogenic) processes, that display an unconformity to possibly over- or underlying adjacent domains.

EXAMPLE 2 Topsoil and Subsoil: These can be domains that group different soil horizon types (e.g. A vs. B horizons), or a special case of fixed depths with only two depth ranges (e.g. 0-15 cm: topsoil and, 15-75 cm: subsoil).

EXAMPLE 3 Depth intervals: They are often used in soil monitoring, sampling of contaminated sites and in modelling and include: (i) depth increments (also called fixed depths) that are often used for sampling, e.g. 0-30cm, 30-60cm, and so on, (ii) a single depth range in which a soil sample (”specimen”) is taken and for which the analytical result is valid, and (iii) soil slicing, that is, profile segmentation according to a specified vector, for instance, either regularly spaced intervals (1cm), or a user-defined vector of segment boundaries (i.e. 0-10, 10-25, 25-50, 50-100). Slicing is used in modelling to generate continuous depth functions for soil properties.
EXAMPLE 4: In the framework of soils deeply modified by human activity, artificial layers may be due to different kinds of deposits (concrete, bricks, …).
SOURCE WD ISO28258, modified

FeatureAttribute.name: layerType
FeatureAttribute.title: layer type
FeatureAttribute.definition: assignation of a layer according to the concept that fits its kind.
FeatureAttribute.description: EXAMPLE Topsoil: meaning the upper part of the natural mineral soil that is generally dark coloured and has a higher content of organic matter and nutrients when compared to the mineral horizons below.

FeatureAttribute.name: layerRockType
FeatureAttribute.title: layer rock type <font color="#ff0000"> </font>
FeatureAttribute.definition: type of the material in which the layer developed.
FeatureAttribute.description: simplified list of terms to “classify” geologic units

FeatureAttribute.name: layerGenesisProcess
FeatureAttribute.title: layer genesis process
FeatureAttribute.definition: last non-pedogenic process (geologic or anthropogenic) that coined the material composition and internal structure of the layer.

FeatureAttribute.name: layerGenesisEnvironment
FeatureAttribute.title: layer genesis environment
FeatureAttribute.definition: setting in which the last non-pedogenic process (geologic or anthropogenic) that coined the material composition and internal structure of the layer took place.
FeatureAttribute.description: The material in which a soil develops is influenced by the environmental situation in which the processes of its formation took place, e.g. sedimentation from water results in quite differently structured layers when it has been deposited in running water than in a lake.

FeatureAttribute.name: layerGenesisProcessState
FeatureAttribute.title: layer genesis process state
FeatureAttribute.definition: indication whether the process specified in layerGenesisProcess is on-going or seized in the past.
FeatureAttribute.description: Process state gives an idea whether current non-pedogenic processes affect the soil or not. E.g. on current floodplains, input of sediments during seasonal flooding events is received, with comparatively young soil development in it, while in older fluvial sediments that are no longer under a regime of seasonal or irregular flooding, soil development might be more advanced.

ApplicationSchema.name: Specialised Observations
ApplicationSchema.definition: Application schema for specialist types of Observations

FeatureType.name: GridObservation
FeatureType.definition: Observation representing a gridded field at a single time instant.
FeatureType.description: A GridObservation is an observation of some phenomenon (or phenomena) over a gridded field. E.g. Output from a model, or rectified, georeferenced satellite data.

The result of a GridObservation is a discrete coverage within a compound spatiotemporal CRS where the domain consists of a two- or three-dimensional grid of points, all having the same time instant temporal component.

FeatureType.name: PointTimeSeriesObservation
FeatureType.definition: Observation that represents a time-series of point measurements of a property at a fixed location in space
FeatureType.description: A PointTimeSeriesObservation is a time series of observations made at the same fixed spatial location e.g. Measurements made repeatedly by a fixed monitoring instrument.

FeatureType.name: ProfileObservation
FeatureType.definition: Observation representing the measurement of a property along a vertical profile in space at a single time instant.
FeatureType.description: A ProfileObservatation is an Observation representing the measurement of a property along a vertical profice in space at a single time instant. For example a CTD profile measuring salinty at different depths in the ocean.

FeatureType.name: TimeLocationValueTriple
FeatureType.title: TimeLocationValue Triple
FeatureType.definition: A triple set of Time, location, value (measurement). For example, at a point along a trajectory.

FeatureAttribute.name: location
FeatureAttribute.definition: Geographic location where value is valid.

FeatureType.name: GridSeriesObservation
FeatureType.definition: Observation representing an evolving gridded field at a succession of time instants.
FeatureType.description: A GridSeriesObservation is a time series of gridded fields representing the same phenomenon (or phenomena) over a series of times. E.g. Ocean model output.

The result of a GridSeriesObservation is a discrete coverage within a compound spatiotemporal CRS where the domain consists of a series of two- or three-dimensional grids of points, each at a successive time instant.

FeatureType.name: MultiPointObservation
FeatureType.definition: Observation that represents a set of measurements all made at exactly the same time but at different locations
FeatureType.description: The MultiPointObservation is an Observation that represents a set of measurements all made at exactly the same time but at different locations, for example a distributed sensor network reporting the temperature at 10am. The result of this observation is a MultiPointCoverage.

FeatureType.name: TrajectoryObservation
FeatureType.definition: Observation representing the measurement of a property along a meandering curve in time and space.
FeatureType.description: A TrajectoryObservatation is an Observation representing the measurement of a property along a meandering curve in time and space. For example a Pollutant concentration from a mobile air quality sensor.

FeatureType.name: PointObservation
FeatureType.title: Point Observation
FeatureType.definition: Observation that represents a measurement of a property at a single point in time and space.
FeatureType.description: The PointObservation represents a single measurement or estimation of a property at a single point in time and space. For example a single temperture measurement at a fixed weather station.

FeatureType.name: PointObservationCollection
FeatureType.definition: A collection of Point Observations.
FeatureType.description: The PointObservationCollection is a collection of separate PointObservations. In the case where it is useful to group together a set of otherwise independent PointObservations the PointObservationCollection should be used to make this grouping. The grouping may be made on any basis e.g. it may be useful to group together PointObservations made by the same instrument or Environmental Facility, or in a particular measurement campaign. Each member of the PointObservationCollection must be a single PointObservation.

FeatureType.name: SpeciesNameType
FeatureType.title: species name type
FeatureType.definition: Identifier and scientific name, including the author, taken from an international reference list, optionally completed by a locally used name and its taxonomic concept relationship to the reference name.
FeatureType.description: The authorized ReferenceSpeciesScheme provides reference species list which defines the ReferenceSpeciesName with its scientific name plus author and ReferenceSpeciesId. The LocalSpeciesName provides nomenclatural and taxonomical information about the locally used species name and the taxonomic concepts implied by the use of this name according to a given reference.

FeatureAttribute.name: referenceSpeciesId
FeatureAttribute.title: reference species id
FeatureAttribute.definition: Identifier of one of the reference lists given by the referenceSpeciesScheme.
FeatureAttribute.description: In the referenceSpeciesScheme the species IDs are linked to scientific names and corresponding authors using GUIDs

FeatureAttribute.name: referenceSpeciesScheme
FeatureAttribute.title: reference species scheme
FeatureAttribute.definition: Reference list defining a nomenclatural and taxonomical standard to which all local names and taxonomic concepts shall be mapped.
FeatureAttribute.description: Code list of accepted PAN-European taxonomical reference lists defining the nomenclature and taxonomical concept of a given species name. This must not be regarded as the ultimate taxonomic truth: this will always change. It serves as a definition of a taxonomic concept described by systematic and synonym relations where other names and there inherent taxonomic concepts can be mapped to. The code list comprises of Eu-Nomen, EUNIS and Natura2000. In these sources harmonized species GUIDs and names are maintained by institutions with an assignment outside INSPIRE and the species names are to be retrieved through webservices using GUIDs. Only one of these list must be used for one taxon. The priority is as follows: 1) EU-Nomen, 2) EUNIS, 3) Natura2000. This implies: if a taxon is listed in EU-Nomen, this reference must be used as first choice. If it is not listed in EU-Nomen, the second choice is EUNIS, if not in EUNIS, Natura2000 can be used.

FeatureAttribute.name: referenceSpeciesName
FeatureAttribute.title: reference species name
FeatureAttribute.definition: The scientific name, including the author, used in the authorized ReferenceSpeciesScheme.
FeatureAttribute.description: The authorized ReferenceSpeciesScheme (EU-Nomen, Unis and Nature Directives) provides reference species lists which defines the ReferenceSpeciesName with its scientific name plus author and ReferenceSpeciesId.

FeatureAttribute.name: localSpeciesId
FeatureAttribute.title: local species id
FeatureAttribute.definition: Identifier used in national nomenclature.
FeatureAttribute.description: The taxonID used in national nomenclature databases.

FeatureAttribute.name: localSpeciesScheme
FeatureAttribute.title: local species scheme
FeatureAttribute.definition: Name of local species classification scheme (bibliographic reference).

FeatureAttribute.name: localSpeciesName
FeatureAttribute.title: local species name
FeatureAttribute.definition: Scientific name, including the author, used in national nomenclature with its national taxonomic concept.
FeatureAttribute.description: The LocalSpeciesName provides nomenclatural and taxonomical information about the locally used species name and the taxonomic concepts implied by the use of this name according to a given reference. If omitted the name and concept given by the referenceSpeciesId according to the referenceSpeciesScheme has been used locally.

FeatureAttribute.name: qualifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: Specifies the taxonomic concept relationship between local species identifier and the reference species identifier.
FeatureAttribute.description: Defines how the local species name conceptually is related to the referenceSpeciesID, either congruent, included in, includes, overlaps or excludes

FeatureType.name: RangeType
FeatureType.title: range type
FeatureType.definition: Value indicating the upper and lower limits of the counting, estimation or calculation of occurrences.

FeatureAttribute.name: upperBound
FeatureAttribute.title: upper bound
FeatureAttribute.definition: The upper limit of the range. If the value of this attribute is null and lowerBound is populated, this implies that the value is between the lowerBound and infinity.

FeatureAttribute.name: lowerBound
FeatureAttribute.title: lower bound
FeatureAttribute.definition: The lower limit of the range. If the value of this attribute is null and upperBound is populated, this implies that the value is between the upperBound and zero.

FeatureType.name: PopulationSizeType
FeatureType.title: population size type
FeatureType.definition: A range value indicating the counted, estimated or calculated occurrences or population sizes, which is defined by an upper and a lower limit.
FeatureType.description: A range density (or abundance) value for species occurrence in the individual species distribution units either counted, estimated or calculated based on defined counting units, or using upper and lower bounds.

FeatureAttribute.name: countingMethod
FeatureAttribute.title: counting method
FeatureAttribute.definition: Method of providing a number for the indication of the abundance of a species within a specific species distribution unit.
FeatureAttribute.description: To obtain a density or abundance estimate the data set provider can either count, estimate or calculate the population abundance.

FeatureAttribute.name: countingUnit
FeatureAttribute.title: counting unit
FeatureAttribute.definition: What has been counted, estimated or calculated when compiling information on the abundance of a species within the species distribution unit.
FeatureAttribute.description: This parameter defines which species population units that has collected or retrieved.
EXAMPLE Colonies, individuals, juvenile, larvae, pairs, shoals, shoots, tufts.

FeatureAttribute.name: populationSize
FeatureAttribute.title: population size
FeatureAttribute.definition: A range value indicating the counted, estimated or calculated occurrences or population sizes using upper and lower bounds.
FeatureAttribute.description: A range density (or abundance) value for species occurrence in the individual species distribution units either counted, estimated or calculated based on defined counting units, or using upper and lower bounds.

FeatureType.name: DistributionInfoType
FeatureType.title: distribution info type
FeatureType.definition: The description of the status of the subject of distribution within the species distribution unit, including the indication of the abundance by counting, estimation or calculation of the number of occurrences or population size of the particular species.

FeatureAttribute.name: occurrenceCategory
FeatureAttribute.title: occurrence category
FeatureAttribute.definition: The species population density in the species distribution unit.
FeatureAttribute.description: A species abundance (population density) in classes (common, rare, very rare, present or absent) in an individual species distribution unit.

FeatureAttribute.name: residencyStatus
FeatureAttribute.title: residency status
FeatureAttribute.definition: Information on the status of residency of a species regarding nativeness versus introduction and permanency.

FeatureAttribute.name: populationSize
FeatureAttribute.title: population size
FeatureAttribute.definition: A range value indicating the counted, estimated or calculated occurrences or population sizes, using an upper and a lower limit.
FeatureAttribute.description: A range density (or abundance) value for species occurrence in the individual species distribution units either counted, estimated or calculated based on defined counting units, or using upper and lower bounds.

FeatureAttribute.name: sensitiveInfo
FeatureAttribute.title: sensitive info
FeatureAttribute.definition: Boolean value that indicates whether the location of a specific species is sensitive.
FeatureAttribute.description: This can be used to filter out or generalize sensitive data. Generalized representation can be larger spatial objects e.g. grid cells.

NOTE A species location e.g. breeding location, of vulnerable, endangered or protected species may by law be excluded from distribution or spatially generalised from detailed locations to lower resolutions in more extensive grid cells to avoid environmental crime.

FeatureAttribute.name: populationType
FeatureAttribute.title: population type
FeatureAttribute.definition: The permanency of populations, particularly with regard to migratory species within a given species distribution unit.
FeatureAttribute.description: Kind of species occurrence or population data that are collected.
EXAMPLE Permanent, reproducing, concentration or wintering (for migratory species).

FeatureAttribute.name: collectedFrom
FeatureAttribute.title: collected from
FeatureAttribute.definition: The date when the collecting of the original species occurrence data started.
FeatureAttribute.description: The starting date for the collection/registration of the primary species occurrence data.

FeatureAttribute.name: collectedTo
FeatureAttribute.title: collected to
FeatureAttribute.definition: The date when the collecting of the original species occurrence data stopped.
FeatureAttribute.description: The last date for the collection/registration of the primary species occurrence data.

FeatureType.name: SpeciesDistributionDataSet
FeatureType.title: species distribution data set
FeatureType.definition: This data set is a collection of individual spatial objects (units) in a distribution of species.
FeatureType.description: Collection of individual spatial objects of allowed geometry where a species occurs.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the spatial object.
FeatureAttribute.description: An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: name
FeatureAttribute.definition: Name of a specific data set provided for Species Distribution.
FeatureAttribute.description: A short descriptive identification name for a specific dataset provided by an institution.
EXAMPLE 1 Redlisted_species_Norway
EXAMPLE 2 Invasive_alien_species_ Ireland
EXAMPLE 3 Articles17_report_Germany

FeatureAttribute.name: domainExtent
FeatureAttribute.title: domain extent
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geographic extent of the domain of the feature collection.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE This date is recorded to enable the generation of change only update files.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE This date is recorded to enable the generation of change only update files.

RelationshipRole.name: member
RelationshipRole.definition: Individual spatial objects in a collection of spatial objects.
RelationshipRole.description: Individual spatial objects of allowed geometry where a species occurs.

RelationshipRole.name: role_T31474
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

RelationshipRole.name: documentBasis
RelationshipRole.definition: Reference to or citation of a document describing a campaign or a legal act which is the basis for the data set.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31473
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: SpeciesDistributionUnit
FeatureType.title: species distribution unit
FeatureType.definition: Occurrence of animal and plant species aggregated by grid, region, administrative unit or other analytical unit.
FeatureType.description: Pan-European, national or local mapping initiatives, resulting in spatial data for species in terrestrial and marine environments, e.g. for birds, insects, mammals, amphibians, reptiles, fish or vascular plants.

NOTE 1 Only species are mentioned in the INSPIRE definition. But earlier INSPIRE documents (INPIRE IMS, 2003) mentions both species or species grouped e.g. to families. So we interprete species as taxa, which means taxonomic units at any systematic rank, like subspecies, species, genus, family etc.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: inspire id
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the spatial object.
FeatureAttribute.description: An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geometry of each unit in a collection.
FeatureAttribute.description: The geometry (e.g. line or polygon) of each individual spatial objects in the collection

FeatureAttribute.name: speciesName
FeatureAttribute.title: species name
FeatureAttribute.definition: Identifier and scientific name, including the author, taken from an international reference list, optionally completed by a locally used name and its taxonomic concept relationship to the reference name.
FeatureAttribute.description: The authorized ReferenceSpeciesScheme provides reference species list which defines the ReferenceSpeciesName with its scientific name plus author and ReferenceSpeciesId. The LocalSpeciesName provides nomenclatural and taxonomical information about the locally used species name and the taxonomic concepts implied by the use of this name according to a given reference. If omitted the name and concept given by the referenceSpeciesId according to the referenceSpeciesScheme has been used locally.

FeatureAttribute.name: distributionInfo
FeatureAttribute.title: distribution info
FeatureAttribute.definition: The description of the subject of distribution (occurrences or population), the indication of the count of observations or population size of the particular species, species group or taxon rank and its distribution or isolation within the species distribution unit.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE This date is recorded to enable the generation of change only update files.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.
FeatureAttribute.description: NOTE This date is recorded to enable the generation of change only update files.

RelationshipRole.name: spatialObject
RelationshipRole.title: spatial object
RelationshipRole.definition: A reference to a another spatial object defining the spatial extent of a distribution unit.
RelationshipRole.description: EXAMPLE A specific administrative area.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S33320
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

ApplicationSchema.name: Statistical Units Base
ApplicationSchema.definition: The base package. It provides most abstract classes required to link the grid and vector view of statistical units.

FeatureType.name: StatisticalUnit
FeatureType.title: Statistical unit
FeatureType.definition: Unit for dissemination or use of statistical information.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [INSPIRE Directive:2007].
EXAMPLE grid cell, point, line, polygon.

NOTE Spatial features of any INSPIRE application schema can be considered as a statistical unit, because all can be used as spatial reference. This class is provided to represent features that are used only to disseminate statistical information and that are not included in another INSPIRE application schema.
This type is abstract.

ApplicationSchema.name: Statistical Units Grid
ApplicationSchema.definition: Package containing classes to represent statistical grids.

FeatureType.name: StatisticalGridCell
FeatureType.title: Statistical grid cell
FeatureType.definition: Unit for dissemination or use of statistical information that is represented as a grid cell.
FeatureType.description: A statistical grid cell is associated with:
- the unique statistical grid cell of its upper level (if any) it is covered by,
- the statistical grid cells of its lower level (if any) it covers.
NB Statistical grid cells are squares.
EXAMPLE In a quadtree structure, some cells are associated with the four cells they are decomposed into.

FeatureAttribute.name: code
FeatureAttribute.title: Code
FeatureAttribute.definition: A cell code.
FeatureAttribute.description: This code is composed of:
1. A coordinate reference system part, represented by the word CRS, followed by the EPSG code.
2. A resolution and position part:

- If the coordinate reference system is projected, the word RES followed by the grid resolution in meters and the letter m. Then, the letter N followed by the northing value in meters, and the letter E followed by the easting value in meters too.

- If the coordinate reference system is not projected, the word RES followed by the grid resolution in degree-minute-second, followed by the word dms. Then the word LON followed by the longitude value in degree-minute-second, and word LAT followed by the latitude value in degree-minute-second.
For both cases, the given position is the position of the lower left cell corner.
NOTE: This code acts like an identifier.

FeatureAttribute.name: geographicalPosition
FeatureAttribute.title: Geographical position
FeatureAttribute.definition: The grid cell lower left corner geographical position.

FeatureAttribute.name: gridPosition
FeatureAttribute.title: Grid position
FeatureAttribute.definition: The grid cell position within the grid based on the grid coordinates.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.title: Geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: The grid cell geometry.

RelationshipRole.name: lowers
RelationshipRole.definition: The immediately lower statistical grid cells.

RelationshipRole.name: upper
RelationshipRole.definition: The immediately upper statistical grid cell.

RelationshipRole.name: grid
RelationshipRole.definition: The grid made up of cells.

RelationshipRole.name: cells
RelationshipRole.definition: The cells composing a grid.

FeatureType.name: StatisticalGridResolution
FeatureType.title: Statistical grid resolution
FeatureType.definition: A statistical unit resolution value.

FeatureAttribute.name: lengthResolution
FeatureAttribute.title: Length resolution
FeatureAttribute.definition: A distance resolution.

FeatureAttribute.name: angleResolution
FeatureAttribute.title: Angle resolution
FeatureAttribute.definition: An angle resolution.

FeatureType.name: StatisticalGrid
FeatureType.title: Statistical grid
FeatureType.definition: A grid composed of statistical cells.
FeatureType.description: Such grid is associated with an upper grid, that has a bigger resolution, and a lower grid that has a lower resolution. Some statistical grids are organised into a hierarchy of grids with different resolutions. The cells composing two linked grids have to satisfy some topological constraints: each cell of the upper grid should be the aggregation of cells of the lower grid.
EXAMPLE The hierarchical structure is a quadtree if the grids are composed of quadrilateral cells and each cell is composed of less than four cells of the lower level.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: INSPIRE identifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the spatial object.
FeatureAttribute.description: An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object.
