The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: EPSGCode
FeatureAttribute.definition: The EPSG code to identify the grid Coordinate Referencing System.
FeatureAttribute.description: This information is relevant only if all cells of the grid have the same CRS.

FeatureAttribute.name: resolution
FeatureAttribute.title: Resolution
FeatureAttribute.definition: The grid resolution.
FeatureAttribute.description: This information is relevant only if all cells of the grid have the same resolution.

FeatureAttribute.name: origin
FeatureAttribute.title: Origin
FeatureAttribute.definition: The position of the origin point of the grid in the specified coordinate reference system (if defined).
FeatureAttribute.description: The origin point is the lower left grid point.

FeatureAttribute.name: width
FeatureAttribute.title: Width
FeatureAttribute.definition: The grid width, in cell number (if defined).

FeatureAttribute.name: height
FeatureAttribute.title: Height
FeatureAttribute.definition: The grid height, in cell number (if defined).

RelationshipRole.name: lower
RelationshipRole.definition: The immediately lower statistical grid.

RelationshipRole.name: upper
RelationshipRole.definition: The immediately upper statistical grid.

FeatureType.name: GridPosition
FeatureType.title: Grid position
FeatureType.definition: A grid cell position within a grid.

FeatureAttribute.name: x
FeatureAttribute.title: x-axis value
FeatureAttribute.definition: The position of the cell on the horizontal axis, starting from the left side, toward the right, from 0 to the grid width -1.

FeatureAttribute.name: y
FeatureAttribute.title: y-axis value
FeatureAttribute.definition: The position of the cell on the vertical axis, starting from the bottom toward the top, from 0 to the grid height -1.

ApplicationSchema.name: Statistical Units Vector
ApplicationSchema.definition: Package containing classes to represent statistical units with vector geometries.

FeatureType.name: Evolution
FeatureType.definition: Representation of vector statistical unit evolution.

FeatureAttribute.name: date
FeatureAttribute.title: Date
FeatureAttribute.definition: The date when the change occured.

FeatureAttribute.name: evolutionType
FeatureAttribute.title: Evolution type
FeatureAttribute.definition: The type of evolution.

FeatureAttribute.name: areaVariation
FeatureAttribute.title: Area variation
FeatureAttribute.definition: The area variation during the evolution. This attribute has to be populated only if the type is "change".

FeatureAttribute.name: populationVariation
FeatureAttribute.title: Population variation
FeatureAttribute.definition: The population variation during the evolution. This attribute has to be populated only if the type is "change".

RelationshipRole.name: finalUnitVersions
RelationshipRole.definition: All the final unit versions concerned by the evolution.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31430
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

RelationshipRole.name: units
RelationshipRole.definition: All the units concerned by the evolution.

RelationshipRole.name: evolutions
RelationshipRole.definition: All the evolutions the statistical unit has encountered.

RelationshipRole.name: initialUnitVersions
RelationshipRole.definition: All the initial unit versions concerned by the evolution.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31434
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: GeometryDescriptor
FeatureType.title: Geometry descriptor
FeatureType.definition: A descriptor for vector statistical unit geometry.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometryType
FeatureAttribute.title: Geometry type
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geometry type.

FeatureAttribute.name: mostDetailedScale
FeatureAttribute.title: Most detailed scale
FeatureAttribute.definition: The most detailed scale the generalised geometry is supposed to be suitable for (expressed as the inverse of an indicative scale).

FeatureAttribute.name: leastDetailedScale
FeatureAttribute.title: Least detailed scale
FeatureAttribute.definition: The least detailed scale the generalised geometry is supposed to be suitable for (expressed as the inverse of an indicative scale).

FeatureType.name: AreaStatisticalUnit
FeatureType.title: Area statistical unit
FeatureType.definition: Vector statistical unit with a surfacic reference geometry.
FeatureType.description: Such object can be composed of other area statistical unit.
EXAMPLE A country area, an administrative unit, a NUTS region.

FeatureAttribute.name: areaValue
FeatureAttribute.title: Area value
FeatureAttribute.definition: The area of the reference geometry.

FeatureAttribute.name: landAreaValue
FeatureAttribute.title: Land area value
FeatureAttribute.definition: The area of the above-water part.

FeatureAttribute.name: livableAreaValue
FeatureAttribute.title: Livable area value
FeatureAttribute.definition: The area of the livable part.

RelationshipRole.name: lowers
RelationshipRole.definition: The area statistical units of the next lower level.

RelationshipRole.name: uppers
RelationshipRole.definition: The area statistical units of the next upper level.

RelationshipRole.name: successors
RelationshipRole.definition: Successors of the area statistical unit.

RelationshipRole.name: predecessors
RelationshipRole.definition: Predecessors of the area statistical unit.

RelationshipRole.name: tesselation
RelationshipRole.definition: The tesselation composed of units.

RelationshipRole.name: units
RelationshipRole.definition: The units composing a tesselation.

RelationshipRole.name: administrativeUnit
RelationshipRole.definition: Administrative units used to buid the area statistical unit.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S32494
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: StatisticalTessellation
FeatureType.title: Statistical tesselation
FeatureType.definition: A tesselation composed of area statistical units.
FeatureType.description: EXAMPLE A NUTS regions coverage.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: INSPIRE identifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the spatial object.
FeatureAttribute.description: An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

RelationshipRole.name: lower
RelationshipRole.definition: The immediately lower statistical tessellation.

RelationshipRole.name: upper
RelationshipRole.definition: The immediately upper statistical tessellation.

FeatureType.name: VectorStatisticalUnitGeometry
FeatureType.title: Vector statistical unit geometry
FeatureType.definition: A geometrical representation for vector statistical units.
FeatureType.description: Vector statistical units can have several representations depending on the context they are used for. It is adviced to produce at least one reference geometry.
EXAMPLE1: A vector statistical units may be represented both by an area and a point geometry. Such point can be the center of gravity or a label location.
EXAMPLE2: For mapping, different generalised representations of vector statistical units are required. These geometries depend on the visualisation scale.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometry
FeatureAttribute.title: Geometry
FeatureAttribute.definition: The geometry.

FeatureAttribute.name: geometryDescriptor
FeatureAttribute.title: Geometry descriptor
FeatureAttribute.definition: The statistical unit geometry descriptor.

FeatureType.name: VectorStatisticalUnit
FeatureType.title: Vector statistical unit
FeatureType.definition: Statistical unit represented as a vector geometry (point, line or surface).
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [INSPIRE Directive:2007].
EXAMPLE grid cell, point, line, polygon.

NOTE Spatial features of any INSPIRE application schema can be considered as a statistical unit, because all can be used as spatial reference. This class is provided to represent features that are used only to disseminate statistical information and that are not included in another INSPIRE application schema.

FeatureAttribute.name: inspireId
FeatureAttribute.title: INSPIRE identifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: External object identifier of the spatial object.
FeatureAttribute.description: An external object identifier is a unique object identifier published by the responsible body, which may be used by external applications to reference the spatial object. The identifier is an identifier of the spatial object, not an identifier of the real-world phenomenon.

FeatureAttribute.name: thematicId
FeatureAttribute.title: Thematic identifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: Descriptive unique object identifier applied to spatial objects in a defined information theme.
FeatureAttribute.description: Some statistical units may be assigned multiple thematic identifiers.
EXAMPLE: NUTS codes are thematic identifiers.

FeatureAttribute.name: country
FeatureAttribute.title: Country
FeatureAttribute.definition: The code of the country the object belongs to.

FeatureAttribute.name: geographicalName
FeatureAttribute.title: Geographical name
FeatureAttribute.definition: Possible geographical names of the object.

FeatureAttribute.name: beginLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: Begin lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: endLifespanVersion
FeatureAttribute.title: End lifespan version
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

FeatureAttribute.name: validityPeriod
FeatureAttribute.title: Validity period
FeatureAttribute.definition: The period when the statistical unit is supposed to be preferably used and not.

FeatureAttribute.name: referencePeriod
FeatureAttribute.title: Reference period
FeatureAttribute.definition: The period when the data is supposed to give a picture of the territorial division in statistical units.

RelationshipRole.name: geometry
RelationshipRole.title: Geometries
RelationshipRole.definition: Geometrical representations of the vector statistical unit.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31431
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

RelationshipRole.name: role_T31813
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: TelecommunicationsCable
FeatureType.title: telecommunications cable
FeatureType.definition: A utility link or link sequence used to convey data signals (PSTN, radio or computer) from one location to another.

FeatureAttribute.name: telecommunicationsCableMaterialType
FeatureAttribute.title: telecommunications cable material type
FeatureAttribute.definition: Type of cable material.

FeatureType.name: ThermalPipe
FeatureType.title: thermal pipe
FeatureType.definition: A pipe used to disseminate heating or cooling from one location to another.

FeatureAttribute.name: thermalProductType
FeatureAttribute.title: thermal product type
FeatureAttribute.definition: The type of thermal product that is conveyed through the thermal pipe.

ApplicationSchema.name: Urban Audit 2009
ApplicationSchema.definition: Example of INSPIRE compliant view of the Urban Audit model (produced by Eurostat).

FeatureType.name: City
FeatureType.definition: Urban audit 2009 city.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [http://www.urbanaudit.org/].

RelationshipRole.name: kernel
RelationshipRole.definition: The kernel of the city.

RelationshipRole.name: city
RelationshipRole.definition: The city of the kernel.

RelationshipRole.name: lowers
RelationshipRole.definition: The city districts composing the city.

RelationshipRole.name: uppers
RelationshipRole.definition: The city composed of city districts.

RelationshipRole.name: LUZ
RelationshipRole.definition: The larger urban zone linked to the city.

RelationshipRole.name: city
RelationshipRole.definition: The city linked to the larger urban zone.

FeatureType.name: SubDistrict
FeatureType.title: Sub district
FeatureType.definition: Urban audit 2009 sub-district.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [http://www.urbanaudit.org/].

RelationshipRole.name: city
RelationshipRole.definition: The city the sub district belong to.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S31455
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

RelationshipRole.name: uppers
RelationshipRole.definition: The district composed of sub districts.

RelationshipRole.name: lowers
RelationshipRole.definition: The sub districts composing a district.

FeatureType.name: Kernel
FeatureType.definition: Urban audit 2009 kernel
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [http://www.urbanaudit.org/].

RelationshipRole.name: LUZ
RelationshipRole.definition: The larger urban zone of the kernel.

RelationshipRole.name: kernel
RelationshipRole.definition: The kernel linked to the larger urban zone.

FeatureType.name: LargerUrbanZone
FeatureType.title: Larger urban zone
FeatureType.definition: Urban audit 2009 larger urban zone.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [http://www.urbanaudit.org/].

FeatureType.name: CityDistrict
FeatureType.title: City district
FeatureType.definition: Urban audit 2009 city district.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [http://www.urbanaudit.org/].

ApplicationSchema.name: Water Framework Directive
ApplicationSchema.definition: The 'Water Framework Directive' application schema contains spatial objects associated with reporting under European Directive 2000/60/EC "establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy".

FeatureType.name: WFDGroundWaterBody
FeatureType.definition: A distinct volume of groundwater within an aquifer or aquifers.
FeatureType.description: NOTE All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.

RelationshipRole.name: relatedGroundWaterBody
RelationshipRole.title: related groundwater body
RelationshipRole.definition: The natural groundwater body that the WFDGroundWaterBody is related to.
RelationshipRole.description: Based on the different assumptions established in Member States the delineation of a WFDGroundWaterBody boundary can differ from the natural GroundWaterBody extent.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S32184
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: WFDCoastalWater
FeatureType.definition: Surface water on the landward side of a line, every point of which is at a distance of one nautical mile on the seaward side from the nearest point of the baseline from which the breadth of territorial waters is measured, extending where appropriate up to the outer limit of transitional waters.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [2000/60/EC Art. 2(7)].

NOTE All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.

FeatureType.name: WFDTransitionalWater
FeatureType.definition: Bodies of surface water in the vicinity of river mouths which are partly saline in character as a result of their proximity to coastal waters but which are substantially influenced by freshwater flows.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [2000/60/EC Art. 2(6)].

NOTE All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.

FeatureType.name: WFDRiverOrLake
FeatureType.definition: Abstract class containing common attributes for a WFD river or lake.
FeatureType.description: NOTE All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.
This type is abstract.

FeatureAttribute.name: large
FeatureAttribute.definition: Rivers with a catchment area > 50,000 km<sup>2</sup>; or rivers and main tributaries that have a catchment area between 5,000 km<sup>2</sup> and 50,000 km<sup>2</sup>.
Lakes that have a surface area > 500 km<sup>2</sup>.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE [WISE GIS Guidance].

FeatureAttribute.name: main
FeatureAttribute.definition: Rivers that have a catchment area > 500 km<sup>2</sup>.
Lakes that have a surface area > 10 km<sup>2</sup>.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE [WISE GIS Guidance].

FeatureType.name: WFDRiver
FeatureType.definition: A body of inland water flowing for the most part on the surface of the land but which may flow underground for part of its course.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [2000/60/EC Art. 2(4)].

NOTE All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.

FeatureType.name: WFDSurfaceWaterBody
FeatureType.definition: A discrete and significant element of surface water.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [Based on 2000/60/EC Art. 2(10)].
EXAMPLE A lake, a reservoir, a stream, river or canal, part of a stream, river or canal, a transitional water or a stretch of coastal water.

NOTE 1 The surface water bodies shall be identified as falling within either one of the following surface water categories - rivers, lakes, transitional waters or coastal waters - or as artificial surface water bodies or heavily modified surface water bodies. [2000/60/EC Ann. II 1.1(ii)]

NOTE 2 All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.
This type is abstract.

FeatureAttribute.name: artificial
FeatureAttribute.definition: 'Artificial water body' means a body of surface water created by human activity.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE [2000/60/EC Art. 2(8)].

FeatureAttribute.name: heavilyModified
FeatureAttribute.definition: 'Heavily modified water body' means a body of surface water which as a result of physical alterations by human activity is substantially changed in character, as designated by the Member State in accordance with the provisions of WFD Annex II.
FeatureAttribute.description: SOURCE [2000/60/EC Art. 2(9)].

FeatureAttribute.name: representativePoint
FeatureAttribute.definition: Representative point of the WFD water body.

RelationshipRole.name: role_S32424
RelationshipRole.description: This is a non-navigable relationship role.

FeatureType.name: WFDLake
FeatureType.definition: A body of standing inland surface water.
FeatureType.description: SOURCE [2000/60/EC Art. 2(5)].

NOTE All WFD spatial object types are regarded as example extensions of the ManagementAreaRestrictionOrRegulationZone spatial object type whose content needs to be further discussed with the relevant WISE and WFD reporting working groups.

FeatureType.name: WaterPipe
FeatureType.title: water pipe
FeatureType.definition: A water pipe used to convey water from one location to another.

FeatureAttribute.name: waterType
FeatureAttribute.title: water type
FeatureAttribute.definition: Type of water.

Value.label: common
Value.definition: The species is common in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: rare
Value.definition: The species is rare in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: very rare
Value.definition: The species is very rare in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: present
Value.definition: The species is present in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: absent
Value.definition: The species has been looked for but not found in the species distribution unit.

Value.label: permitted
Value.definition: The activity is allowed to be performed within the zone.
Value.description: NOTE 1: To achieve or maintain good environmental status only a specific activity or activities may be allowed to be performed in the zone.
NOTE 2: If an activity is only allowed between a particular time period then this should be documented in the validTime attribute.

Value.label: restricted
Value.definition: An activity is limited to only be performed within specific bounds.
Value.description: NOTE 1: To achieve or maintain good environmental status an activity may be restricted to mitigate the risk of environmental degradation.
NOTE 2: If an activity is restricted between a particular time period then this should be documented in the validTime attribute
EXAMPLE: Water abstraction: is restricted and controlled by licence where the operator may be limited to abstracting a specific amount of water per day.

Value.label: prohibited
Value.definition: An activity is not allowed to be performed within the zone.
Value.description: NOTE 1:To achieve or maintain good environmental status specific activity or activities may not be allowed to be performed in the zone.
NOTE 2: If an activity is prohibited within a particular time period then this should be documented in the validTime attribute.

Value.label: promoted
Value.definition: An activity that is positively promoted or introduced within the zone to achieve good environmental status.

Value.label: boulders
Value.definition: Large water- or weather-worn stones.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: clay
Value.definition: A stiff tenacious fine-grained earth consisting mainly of hydrated aluminosilicates, which become more plastic when water is added and can be moulded and dried.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: gravel
Value.definition: Small water-worn or pounded stones.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: mud
Value.definition: Soft wet soil, sand, dust, and/or other earthy matter.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: rock
Value.definition: Stones of any size.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: sand
Value.definition: Granular material consisting of small eroded fragments of (mainly siliceous) rocks, finer than gravel and larger than a coarse silt grain.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: shingle
Value.definition: Small, loose, rounded waterworn pebbles, especially as accumulated on a seashore.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: stone
Value.definition: Pieces of rock or mineral substance (other than metal) of definite form and size, usually artificially shaped, and used for some special purpose.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: groundLevel
Value.definition: The Earth’s surface

Value.label: lowestAstronomicalTide
Value.definition: The lowest tide level that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.

Value.label: meanSeaLevel
Value.definition: The average height of the sea at a tide station measured from a fixed predetermined reference level.
Value.description: Ordnance Datum, often used as a reference point for defining vertical heights, uses the mean Sea Level as its reference point and therefore is also included within this value.

Value.label: seafloor
Value.definition: The bottom of a sea or ocean.

Value.label: coaxial
Value.definition: Coaxial cable.
Value.description: A coaxial cable, or coax, is an electrical cable with an inner conductor surrounded by a flexible, tubular insulating layer, surrounded by a tubular conducting shield.

Value.label: opticalFiber
Value.definition: Fibre-optic cable.
Value.description: A fiber optic cable is composed of thin filaments of glass through which light beams are transmitted to carry large amounts of data. The optical fibers are surrounded by buffers, strength members, and jackets for protection, stiffness, and strength. A fiber-optic cable may be an all-fiber cable, or contain both optical fibers and metallic conductors.

Value.label: twistedPair
Value.definition: Twisted pair (copper) cable.
Value.description: A copper cable is a group of metallic conductors (copper wires) bundled together that are capable of carrying voice and data transmissions. The copper wires are bound together, usually with a protective sheath, a strength member, and insulation between individual conductors and the entire group.

Value.label: other
Value.definition: Other.

Value.label: equalTo
Value.definition: Exactly equal to

Value.label: notEqualTo
Value.definition: Not exactly equal to

Value.label: lessThan
Value.definition: Less than

Value.label: greaterThan
Value.definition: Greater Than

Value.label: lessThanOrEqualTo
Value.definition: Less than or exactly equal to

Value.label: greaterThanOrEqualTo
Value.definition: Greater than or exactly equal to

Value.label: counted
Value.definition: The units defined by the countUnitValues have been counted.

Value.label: estimated
Value.definition: The units defined by the countUnitValues have been estimated.

Value.label: calculated
Value.definition: The units defined by the countUnitValues have been calculated by some modelling technique.

Value.label: biogas
Value.definition: A gas composed principally of methane and carbon dioxide produced by anaerobic digestion of biomass.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: geothermal
Value.definition: Energy available as heat emitted from within the earth's crust, usually in the form of hot water or steam. This energy production is the difference between the enthalpy of the fluid produced in the production borehole and that of the fluid eventually disposed of. It is exploited at suitable sites for electricity generation or directly as heat.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: hydro power
Value.definition: Potential and kinetic energy of water converted into electricity in hydroelectric plants.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: industrial waste
Value.definition: Waste of industrial non-renewable origin (solids or liquids) combusted directly for the production of electricity and/or heat.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: liquid biofuels
Value.definition: Liquid biofuels are biogasoline, bio-diesels or other biofuels directly used as fuel.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: municipal solid waste
Value.definition: <font color="#222226">Waste produced by households, industry, hospitals and the tertiary sector which contains biodegradable materials that are incinerated at specific installations.</font>
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: solar photovoltaic
Value.definition: Sunlight converted into electricity by the use of solar cells usually made of semi-conducting material which, when exposed to light, will generate electricity.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: solar thermal
Value.definition: Heat from solar radiation that can consist of solar thermal-electric plants or of equipment for the production of heat.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: solid biomass
Value.definition: Covers organic, non-fossil material of biological origin which may be used as fuel for heat production or electricity generation.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: tide, wave, ocean
Value.definition: Mechanical energy derived from tidal movement, wave motion or ocean current and exploited for electricity generation.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: wind
Value.definition: Kinetic energy of wind exploited for electricity generation in wind turbines.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: crude oil
Value.definition: Crude oil is a mineral oil of natural origin comprising a mixture of hydrocarbons and associated impurities, such as sulphur. It exists in the liquid phase under normal surface temperature and pressure and its physical characteristics (density, viscosity, etc.) are highly variable.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: hard Coal
Value.definition: Black, combustible, solid, organic fossil sediment often referred to as High Rank, due to their high calorific value, or Black Coals, given their physical characteristic This category includes anthracite, coking coal and other bituminous coal.
Value.description: These coals have a gross calorific value greater than 23865 kJ/kg (5 700 kcal/kg) on an ashfree but moist basis and with a mean random reflectance of vitrinite of at least 0.6.
SOURCE Adapted from IEA (2011): Coal Information 2011 Edition - Documentation For Beyond 2020 Files and Directive 2008/1099/EC.

Value.label: low-rank coal
Value.definition: Combustible brown to black organic fossil sediment which are non-agglomerating and are often referred to as Low Rank Coals due to their lower calorific value or Brown Coals, due to their physical characteristics. This category includes both sub-bituminous coals and lignite.
Value.description: These coals have gross calorific values less that 23 865 kJ/kg (5 700 kcal/kg) on an ash free but moist basis. The sub type of sub-bituminous coal refers to non-agglomerating coal with a gross calorific value between 17 435 kJ/kg (4 165 kcal/kg) and 23 865 kJ/kg (5 700 kcal/kg) containing more than 31% volatile matter on a dry mineral matter free basis.
Lignite is a non-agglomerating coal with a gross calorific value less than 17 435 kJ/kg (4 165 kcal/kg) and greater than 31% volatile matter on a dry mineral matter free basis.
SOURCE Adapted from IEA (2011): Coal Information 2011 Edition - Documentation For Beyond 2020 Files and Directive 2008/1099/EC.

Value.label: natural gas
Value.definition: Gases occurring in underground deposits, whether liquefied or gaseous, consisting mainly of methane.
Value.description: It includes both non-associated gas originating from fields producing hydrocarbons only in gaseous form, and associated gas produced in association with crude oil as well as methane recovered from coal mines (colliery gas) or from coal seams (coal seam gas). It does not include gases created by anaerobic digestion of biomass (e.g. municipal or sewage gas) nor gasworks gas.
SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: natural gas liquids
Value.definition: Liquid or liquefied hydrocarbons recovered from natural gas in separation facilities or gas processing plants.
Value.description: SOURCE Adapted from Energy Statistics Regulation EC 1099/2008 .

Value.label: oil sands
Value.definition: Oil sands, tar sands or, more technically, bituminous sands, are loose sand or partially consolidated sandstone saturated with a dense and extremely viscous form of petroleum technically referred to as bitumen.

Value.label: oil shales
Value.definition: Oil shale, also known as kerogen shale, is an organic-rich fine-grained sedimentary rock containing kerogen (immature hydrocarbons).

Value.label: peat
Value.definition: A combustible soft, porous or compressed, sedimentary deposit of plant origin with high water content (up to 90 % in the raw state), easily cut, of light to dark brown colour.
Value.description: Peat used for non-energy purposes is not included.

SOURCE Adapted from Directive 2008/1099/EC which is also without prejudice to the definition of renewable energy sources in "Directive 2001/77/EC and to the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas inventories.

Value.label: airQualityManagementZone
Value.definition: Part of the territory of a Member State, as delimited by that Member State for the purposes of air quality assessment and management.
Value.description: SOURCE: Air Quality Directive (2008/50/EC).

Value.label: noiseRestrictionZone
Value.definition: An area delimited by a competent authority to manage and mitigate noise pollution.
This includes agglomerations and quiet areas (in agglomerations and open country) as defined in the Environmental Noise Directive (2002/49/EC).
Value.description: NOTE: Noise restriction zones may also be defined to manage noise exposure relating to transport (airports, roads, rail), entertainment venues, recreational activities, construction, etc.

Value.label: animalHealthRestrictionZone
Value.definition: Restriction zones established for the control and eradiation of notifiable animal diseases
Value.description: EXAMPLE: Bluetongue Restriction Zones (Council Directive 2000/75/EC).
EXAMPLE: Avian Influenze Restriction Zones (Council Directive 2005/94/EC).
EXAMPLE: African Horse Sickness (Council Directive 92/35/EEC).

Value.label: prospectingAndMiningPermitArea
Value.definition: The area on which the prospection or extraction of any mineral has been authorised and for which that right or permit is granted.
Value.description: EXAMPLE: Directive 94/22/EC on conditions for granting and using authorisations for the prospection, exploration and production of hydrocarbons, stipulates that the limits of the geographical areas covered by an authorisation and the duration of that authorisation must be determined in proportion to what is justified in terms of the best possible exercise of the activities from an economic and technical point of view.

Value.label: regulatedFairwayAtSeaOrLargeInlandWater
Value.definition: Regulated navigation areas port-to-port established in accordance with Decision 884/2004/EC of the European Parliament and Council of 29 April 2004 amending Decision No 1692/96/EC on Community guidelines for the development of the trans - European transport network to organise sailing traffic, prevent accident and pollution.

Value.label: restrictedZonesAroundContaminatedSites
Value.definition: Zones established to protect human, plant and animal health and control movement and development within a contaminated site.
Value.description: EXAMPLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant Exclusion Zone which was established to evacuate the local population and to prevent people from entering the heavily contaminated territory.
EXAMPLE: Zone established around an area suffering from soil contamination to restrict development and protect human health.

Value.label: areaForDumpingOfWaste
Value.definition: Area affected by uncontrolled disposal of waste as defined in Waste Framework Directive (2006/12/EC) Art 4.

Value.label: coastalZoneManagementArea
Value.definition: Area in which "integrated coastal zone management" takes place.
Value.description: DEFINITION: "Integrated coastal zone management” is a dynamic process for the sustainable management and use of coastal zones, taking into account at the same time the fragility of coastal ecosystems and landscapes, the diversity of activities and uses, their interactions, the maritime orientation of certain activities and uses and their impact on both the marine and land parts.
SOURCE: Protocol on Integrated Coastal Zone Management in the Mediterranean - signed in Madrid on 20-21 January 2008.

Value.label: drinkingWaterProtectionArea
Value.definition: Area in which waste water leakage, use of fertilizer or pesticides, or establishment of waste disposal sites are prohibited.
Value.description: EXAMPLE: From Directive 80/778, relating to the quality of water intended for human consumption.

According to the article 8 providing that Member States shall take all the necessary measures to ensure that any substances used in the preparation of water for human consumption do not remain in concentrations higher than the maximum admissible.

Value.label: nitrateVulnerableZone
Value.definition: Areas of land which drain into polluted or threatened waters and which contribute to nitrate pollution.
Value.description: SOURCE: Art 3 of Council Directive 91/676/EEC of 12 December 1991 concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources.

Value.label: marineRegion
Value.definition: Marine regions and their subregions are sea regions designated for the purpose of assessment, management and regulation.
Value.description: For each Marine Region a marine strategy shall be developed and implemented to maintain and improve good environmental status.
SOURCE: Marine Strategy Framework Directive (2008/56/EC).

Value.label: riverBasinDistrict
Value.definition: Area of land and sea, made up of one or more neighbouring river basins together with their associated groundwaters and coastal waters, identified under Article 3(1) as the main unit for management of river basins.
Value.description: SOURCE: Art 2 (15) of DIRECTIVE 2000/60/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy.
NOTE: A river basin district can either be an international or national river basin district or a sub unit of management.

NOTE 2: The relatedZone role should be used to link river basin districts. For example, a national river basin district should include a relatedZone attribute linking it to the international river basin district.

Value.label: bathingWaters
Value.definition: Coastal waters or inland waters (rivers, lakes) explicitly authorised, or not prohibited for recreational bathing by large numbers of people.
Value.description: NOTE: Bathing waters are set limits for physical, chemical and microbiological parameters to ensuring clean bathing waters to protect public health and the environment.

Value.label: floodManagementUnit
Value.definition: Coastal areas or individual river basins assigned as the unit of management established for the assessment and management of flood risk.
Value.description: These are coastal areas or individual river basins assigned as a unit of management different from those assigned pursuant to Article 3(1) of Directive 2000/60/EC.
SOURCE: 2007/60/EC Art 3(2)b.

Value.label: sensitiveArea
Value.definition: Sensitive areas are surface waters (freshwater, estuaries and coastal waters) that require protection against eutrophication.
Value.description: SOURCE: Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive (91/271/EEC).

Value.label: designatedWaters
Value.definition: Marine, coastal or surface waters designated by Member States as needing protection or improvement in order to support fish life.
Value.description: Member States are required to define designated waters to protect freshwater fish and shellfish by the Fisheries Directive (2006/44/EC) and Shellfish Waters Directive (2006/113/EEC).

Value.label: plantHealthProtectionZone
Value.definition: Protection zone within which protective measures are established against the introduction of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread.
Value.description: SOURCE: COMMISSION REGULATION (EC) No 690/2008.

Value.label: potable
Value.definition: Potable water.
Value.description: Potable water or drinking water is water of sufficiently high quality that can be consumed or used without risk of immediate or long term harm.

Value.label: raw
Value.definition: Raw water.
Value.description: Raw water is water taken from the environment, and is subsequently treated or purified to produce potable water in a water purification works. Raw water should not be considered safe for drinking or washing without further treatment.

Value.label: salt
Value.definition: Salt water.
Value.description: Salt water or saline water is a general term for water that contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts (NaCl).

Value.label: treated
Value.definition: Treated water.
Value.description: Treated water is the water that went throgh treatment proces.Treatment processes are the ones commonly used in water purification plants.

Value.label: natural
Value.definition: An indication that a spatial object is natural.

Value.label: manMade
Value.definition: An indication that a spatial object is man-made.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: contiguous zone
Value.definition: A zone contiguous to a territorial sea of a coastal State, which may not extend beyond 24 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured.
Value.description: SOURCE IHO Dictionary,S-32, 5th Edition.
NOTE 1 The contiguous zone is adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State.

NOTE 2 In the contiguous zone a coastal State may exercise the control necessary to prevent and punish infringements of its customs, fiscal, immigration, or sanitary laws and regulations within its territory or territorial sea. See also Article 33 of United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label: continental shelf
Value.definition: A maritime zone beyond and adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State whose outer boundary is determined in accordance with Article 76 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
Value.description: NOTE 1 The continental shelf is adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State. The continental shelf overlaps with the extent of contiguous zone and exclusive economic zone of a coastal State.
NOTE 2 Art. 76 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea:

1. The continental shelf of a coastal State comprises the seabed and subsoil of the submarine areas that extend beyond its territorial sea throughout the natural prolongation of its land territory to the outer edge of the continental margin, or to a distance of 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured where the outer edge of the continental margin does not extend up to that distance.
2. The continental shelf of a coastal State shall not extend beyond the limits provided for in paragraphs 4 to 6.

3. The continental margin comprises the submerged prolongation of the land mass of the coastal State, and consists of the seabed and subsoil of the shelf, the slope and the rise. It does not include the deep ocean floor with its oceanic ridges or the subsoil thereof.

4. (a) For the purposes of this Convention, the coastal State shall establish the outer edge of the continental margin wherever the margin extends beyond 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured, by either:

(i) a line delineated in accordance with paragraph 7 by reference to the outermost fixed points at each of which the thickness of sedimentary rocks is at least 1 per cent of the shortest distance from such point to the foot of the continental slope; or
(ii) a line delineated in accordance with paragraph 7 by reference to fixed points not more than 60 nautical miles from the foot of the continental slope.
(b) In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the foot of the continental slope shall be determined as the point of maximum change in the gradient at its base.

5. The fixed points comprising the line of the outer limits of the continental shelf on the seabed, drawn in accordance with paragraph 4 (a)(i) and (ii), either shall not exceed 350 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured or shall not exceed 100 nautical miles from the 2,500 metre isobath, which is a line connecting the depth of 2,500 metres.

6. Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 5, on submarine ridges, the outer limit of the continental shelf shall not exceed 350 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured. This paragraph does not apply to submarine elevations that are natural components of the continental margin, such as its plateaux, rises, caps, banks and spurs.

7. The coastal State shall delineate the outer limits of its continental shelf, where that shelf extends beyond 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured, by straight lines not exceeding 60 nautical miles in length, connecting fixed points, defined by coordinates of latitude and longitude.

8. Information on the limits of the continental shelf beyond 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured shall be submitted by the coastal State to the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf set up under Annex II on the basis of equitable geographical representation. The Commission shall make recommendations to coastal States on matters related to the establishment of the outer limits of their continental shelf. The limits of the shelf established by a coastal State on the basis of these recommendations shall be final and binding.

9. The coastal State shall deposit with the Secretary-General of the United Nations charts and relevant information, including geodetic data, permanently describing the outer limits of its continental shelf. The Secretary-General shall give due publicity thereto.
10. The provisions of this article are without prejudice to the question of delimitation of the continental shelf between States with opposite or adjacent coasts.

Value.label: exclusive economic zone
Value.definition: An area beyond and adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State, subject to the specific legal regime under which the rights and jurisdiction of the coastal State and the rights and freedoms of other States are governed by the relevant provisions of the United Nations Convention on Law of the Sea.
Value.description: SOURCE Article 55 of United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
NOTE 1 The exclusive economic zone is adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State. Exclusive economic zone overlaps with the extent of contiguous zone of a coastal State.

NOTE 2 Under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), the coastal States are entitled to an exclusive economic zone extending no further than 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the Member State's territorial sea is measured.

NOTE 3 In contrast to the continental shelf, an exclusive economic zone must be explicitly proclaimed or installed by the coastal state and includes, besides the seabed and its subsoil, the waters super-adjacent to the seabed.

Value.label: internal waters
Value.definition: The waters on the landward side of the baselines of the territorial sea of the coastal State.
--Description--
SOURCE Article 5 of United Nations Convention of Law on the Sea.

NOTE 1 The internal waters is the zone between the shoreline and the baseline (see the Data Specification for "Sea Regions” INSPIRE theme). The delineation of the landward boundary of the internal waters is regulated differently in different countries.
NOTE 2 The internal waters can include waterways, mouths of the rivers and bays.

Value.label: territorial sea
Value.definition: A belt of sea of a defined breadth not exceeding 12 nautical miles measured from the baselines determined in accordance to the United Nations Convention of Law on the Sea.
Value.description: SOURCE IHO Dictionary, S-32, Fifth Edition.

NOTE The sovereignty of a coastal State extends, beyond its land territory and internal waters and, in the case of an archipelagic State, its archipelagic waters, to an adjacent belt of sea, is described as the territorial sea. This sovereignty extends to the air space over the territorial sea as well as to its bed and subsoil.
The sovereignty over the territorial sea is exercised subject to the United Nations Convention of Law on the Sea (UNCLOS) and to other rules of international law.

Value.label: LL
Value.definition: Lateral line.
Value.description: A lateral line is a small-diameter pipe that runs from the main line to the customer premises.

Value.label: LL_Combination
Value.definition: Lateral line that transports a combination of sanitary and storm water.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports a combination of sanitary and storm water.

Value.label: LL_Commercial
Value.definition: Lateral line that transport commercial-origin wastewater.
Value.description: Lateral line that transport wastewater from commercial facilities.

Value.label: LL_Domestic
Value.definition: Lateral line that transports domestic sanitary water.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports domestic wastewater.

Value.label: LL_Irrigation
Value.definition: Irrigation lateral line.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports irrigation wastewater.

Value.label: LL_Storm
Value.definition: Lateral line that transports storm water.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports storm water.

Value.label: ML
Value.definition: Main line.
Value.description: A main line is a large-diameter pipe that carries sewer from the source through the network.

Value.label: ML_GM
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main.
Value.description: A gravity main is a type of main line that is unpressurized and relies on gravity to move the water through the main.

Value.label: ML_GM_Collector
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's collector.
Value.description: A collector is a pipe that collects and transports wastewater to a treatment plant or disposal system. Service laterals connect to collectors.

Value.label: ML_GM_Culvert
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's culvert.
Value.description: A culvert is a pipe used to channel water e.g. underneath a road, railway or embankment.

Value.label: ML_GM_InLineStorage
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's in-line storage.
Value.description: In-line storage involves retaining wet-weather flow in the pipe for small rainstorms.

Value.label: ML_GM_Interceptor
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's interceptor.
Value.description: Large sewer line that controls the flow of sewage to the treatment plant. In a storm it allows some of the sewage to flow directly into a receiving stream, thus keeping it from overflowing onto the streets.

Value.label: ML_GM_InvertedSiphon
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's inverted siphon.
Value.description: An inverted siphon is a pipe that must dip below an obstruction to form a „U“ shaped flow path. Inverted siphons are commonly used for preventing smelly sewer gases from coming back out of drains.

Value.label: ML_GM_OpenChannel
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's open channel.
Value.description: An open channel is a channel open to the environment that transmits raw water and drainage.

Value.label: ML_GM_Outfall
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's outfall.
Value.description: Outfalls are the conduit leading to the final disposal point or area for wastewater and drainage. Outfalls discharge into a receiving water body, such as a stream, river, lake, ocean, or other surface, or groundwater.

Value.label: ML_GM_Overflow
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's overflow.
Value.description: An overflow connects a chamber or pipe to another part of the system or outfall during overload conditions or peak flows.

Value.label: ML_GM_Tunnel
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's tunnel.
Value.description: Tunnels are used to transmit sewer through mountains or deep below the ground. Tunnels are generally created in bedrock and may contain features such as pipes and ducts (conduits) within the tunnel.

Value.label: ML_PM
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main.
Value.description: A pressurized main is a type of main line that is pressurized. Pressure sewers are particularly adaptable for rural or
semi-rural communities where public contact with
effluent from failing drain fields presents a substantial
health concern.

NOTE There are numerous types of PressurizedMains in the sewer distribution model; they include AirRelease, BlowOff, Bypass, ChemicalInjection, DistributionMain, Interconnect, PipeBridge, SamplingStation, and TransmissionMain.

Value.label: ML_PM_ForceMain
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's force main.

Value.label: ML_PM_PipeBridge
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's pipe bridge.

Value.label: ML_PM_Pressure
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's pressure.

Value.label: ML_PM_Vacuum
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's vacuum.

Value.label: disused
Value.definition: The facility is no longer used, but is not being or has not been decommissioned.

Value.label: functional
Value.definition: The facility is functional.

Value.label: projected
Value.definition: The facility is being designed. Construction has not yet started.

Value.label: under construction
Value.definition: The facility is under construction and not yet functional. This applies only to the initial construction of the facility and not to maintenance work.

Value.label: decommissioned
Value.definition: The facility is no longer used and is being or has been decommissioned.

Value.label: height
Value.definition: Elevation property measured along a plumb line in a direction opposite to Earth's gravity field (upwards).
Value.description: NOTE This definition intentionally avoids making reference to complex geodetic terms. It is only intended to specify the direction in which the elevation property has been measured.

Value.label: depth
Value.definition: Elevation property measured along a plumb line in a direction coincident to Earth's gravity field (downwards).
Value.description: NOTE This definition intentionally avoids making reference to complex geodetic terms. It is only intended to specify the direction in which the elevation property has been measured.

Value.label: eunis
Value.definition: EUNIS habitat classification.
Value.description: http://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/
data/nationally-designated-areas-national-cdda-3/
eunis-habitat-classification.

Value.label: habitats directive
Value.definition: Habitats Directive Annex I habitats.
Value.description: http://bd.eionet.europa.eu/article17/reference_portal.

Value.label: marine strategy framework directive
Value.definition: Marine Strategy Framework Directive, Annex III table 3.
Value.description: http://bd.eionet.europa.eu/article17/reference_portal.

Value.label: eunomen
Value.definition: Names and taxonomic concepts as defined by the Pan European Species Inventory, published by eunomen.eu/portal.

Value.label: eunis
Value.definition: Names and taxonomic concepts as defined by the EUNIS Species list.

Value.label: nature directives
Value.definition: Names and taxonomic concepts as defined by the nature directives species list.

Value.label: agreed
Value.definition: The edge-matched boundary has been agreed between neighbouring administrative units and is stable now.

Value.label: not agreed
Value.definition: The edge-matched boundary has not yet been agreed between neighbouring administrative units and could be changed.

Value.label: dry
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing infrequently, generally only during and/or immediately after heavy precipitation.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE The waterbody is often vegetated (for example: with shrubs); such a streambed in the Southwestern United States is termed a 'derramadero'.

Value.label: ephemeral
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing during and immediately after precipitation.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: intermittent
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing for part of the year.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: perennial
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing continuously throughout the year as its bed lies below the water table.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: international
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the international level.

Value.label: national
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the national level.

Value.label: regional
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the regional level.

Value.label: local
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the local level.

Value.label: congruent
Value.definition: The concepts are identical.

Value.label: included in
Value.definition: The concept of the localSpeciesName is included in the concept of the referenceSpeciesName.

Value.label: includes
Value.definition: The concept of the localSpeciesName is includes the concept of the referenceSpeciesName.

Value.label: overlaps
Value.definition: The concepts overlap, but each one has a part that is not included in the other.

Value.label: excludes
Value.definition: The concepts exclude each other.

Value.label: wintering
Value.definition: Uses the site during the winter.

Value.label: reproducing
Value.definition: Uses the site to raise young (e.g. breeding, nesting).

Value.label: concentration
Value.definition: Site used for staging or roosting or migration stop/over or for moulting outside the breeding grounds and excluding wintering.

Value.label: permanent
Value.definition: To be found throughout the year on the site (non-migratory species or plant, resident population of migratory species).

Value.label: collection
Value.definition: tbd - definition: mainly used for collection of sewage water

Value.label: distribution
Value.definition: tbd-definition: mainly used for delivery of water/elelectricity/etc from a distribution point to consumers

Value.label: private
Value.definition: tbd-def: Private utility network cable/pipe owned by a user (not part of a public distribution utility network) e.g. electricity cables linking facilities

Value.label: transport
Value.definition: tbd - def: mainly used for transportation of water/electr/etc over long distances to distribution points

Value.label: combined
Value.definition: Combined wastewater.
Value.description: A combined wastewater sewer is a type of sewer system that collects sanitary sewage and stormwater runoff in a single pipe system.

Value.label: reclaimed
Value.definition: Reclaimed water.
Value.description: Reclaimed water, sometimes called recycled water, is former wastewater (sewage) that has been treated to remove solids and certain impurities, and then used in sustainable landscaping irrigation or to recharge groundwater aquifers.

Value.label: sanitary
Value.definition: Sanitary wastewater.
Value.description: Sanitary sewers remove waste products from peoples' home and send them underground to a treatment plant.

Value.label: storm
Value.definition: Storm runoff wastewater.
Value.description: Storm wastewater drains gather rain and storm runoff and direct them to wetlands and lakes. Ditches and curb line grates are storm drains.

Value.label: monday
Value.definition: Monday is the day of the week between Sunday and Tuesday

Value.label: tuesday
Value.definition: Tuesday is the day of the week between Monday and Wednesday.

Value.label: wednesday
Value.definition: Wednesday is the day of the week between Tuesday and Thursday.

Value.label: thursday
Value.definition: Thursday is the day of the week between Wednesday and Friday.

Value.label: friday
Value.definition: Friday is the day of the week between Thursday and Saturday.

Value.label: saturday
Value.definition: Saturday is the day of the week between Friday and Sunday.

Value.label: sunday
Value.definition: Sunday is the day of the week between Saturday and Monday.

Value.label: weekdays
Value.definition: Weekdays refers to all days contained within a working week: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

Value.label: weekends
Value.definition: Weekdays refers to all days contained within a weekend: Saturday and Sunday.

Value.label: publicHoliday
Value.definition: Any day that is designated as a public holiday within a Member State.

Value.label: modelling
Value.definition: The area has been computed according to a model.

Value.label: indirectDetermination
Value.definition: The area has been defined by interpretation of available data and/or information.

Value.label: onGroundSurface
Value.definition: The spatial object is on ground level.

Value.label: suspendedOrElevated
Value.definition: The spatial object is suspended or elevated.

Value.label: underground
Value.definition: The spatial object is underground.

Value.label: agricultureAndAquaculture
Value.definition: Activities related to agriculture and aquaculture.

Value.label: environmentalPollution
Value.definition: Activities causing environmental pollution.

Value.label: resourceManagement
Value.definition: Activities related to mining and extraction of materials.

Value.label: fishingHuntingOrCollecting
Value.definition: Activities related to fishing, hunting and/or collecting of flora or fauna.

Value.label: transportation
Value.definition: Activities related to transportation.

Value.label: landUseAndPlanning
Value.definition: Activities related to land use and planning.

Value.label: riskManagement
Value.definition: Activities related to risk management.

Value.label: conservation
Value.definition: Activities related to conservation of nature and cultural heritage.

Value.label: plantAndAnimalHealth
Value.definition: Activities related to protection and eradication of harmful organisms and disease related to plant and animal health.

Value.label: international
Value.definition: An international legal act or convention.

Value.label: european
Value.definition: A legal act of the European Union.

Value.label: national
Value.definition: A legal act at national level.

Value.label: sub-national
Value.definition: A legal act at sub-national level.
Value.description: NOTE The sub-national level encompasses both regional or local legislative instruments.

Value.label: digital terrain model
Value.definition: Digital terrain model.
Value.description: EXAMPLE Buildings, bridges or vegetation do not form part of a DTM.
NOTE 1 For DTM surfaces describing the floor of water bodies (e.g. the sea-floor), the water bodies are not considered as part of the Earth's bare surface. Hence, they are excluded from the DTM.
NOTE 2 For DTM surfaces in which any features placed on the Earth's bare surface have not been totally filtered and excluded, the deviations must be explained in the metadata.

Value.label: digital surface model
Value.definition: Digital surface model.
Value.description: EXAMPLE 1 Vegetation, buildings and bridges are examples of static features.
EXAMPLE 2 Cars, trucks and other dynamic features are examples of temporary phenomena.

NOTE 1 For DSM surfaces describing the floor of water bodies (e.g. the sea-floor) and those features placed on it, the water bodies are not considered as part of the Earth's bare surface. Hence, they are excluded from the DSM.
NOTE 2 For DSM surfaces in which any temporary phenomena have not been totally filtered and excluded, the deviations must be explained in the metadata.

Value.label: master
Value.definition: Contour at a vertical distance which is multiple to the equidistance parameter (corresponding to a certain multiple of the normal contour vertical interval) associated with the nominal scale.

Value.label: ordinary
Value.definition: Contour at the equidistance parameter (corresponding to the normal contour vertical interval) associated with the nominal scale, and which is not a master contour.

Value.label: auxiliary
Value.definition: A supplementary contour – not corresponding to the normal contour vertical interval – estimated or interpolated from surrounding contours, used in areas where there is insufficient height information for elevation mapping purposes or to control the creation of a digital elevation model.
Value.description: NOTE This term is equivalent to the value 'intermediate' used in some Member States.

Value.label: natura 2000 and emerald bio-geographical region
Value.definition: A set of code lists to be used to define the Natura 2000 and Emerald network Biogeographical regions.

Value.label: environmental stratification
Value.definition: A set of code lists to be used to define the Environmental Stratification.

Value.label: natural vegetation
Value.definition: A set of code lists to be used to define the natural vegetation.

Value.label: marine strategy framework directive
Value.definition: A set of codes to be used for the Marine Stategy Framework Diretive region classification.

Value.label: edge matched
Value.definition: The boundaries of neighbouring administrative units have the same set of coordinates.

Value.label: not edge matched
Value.definition: The boundaries of neighbouring administrative units do not have the same set of coordinates.

Value.label: aluminium
Value.definition: Aluminium.

Value.label: copper
Value.definition: Copper.

Value.label: steel
Value.definition: Steel.

Value.label: NPD
Value.definition: Norwegian Petroleum Directorate classification (NPD-2001)
Value.description: The Norwegian Petroleum Directorate classification (NPD-2001) is based on the SPE/WPC/AAPG 2000 classification but expanded to utilize categories that differentiate projects based on their commerciality, that is, their maturity towards full producing status.

Value.label: PERC
Value.definition: Pan-European Code for Reporting of Exploration Results, Mineral Resources and Reserves (PERC).
Value.description: The PERC Code for Reporting of Exploration Results, Mineral Resources and Mineral Reserves sets out minimum standards, recommendations and guidelines for Public Reporting of Exploration Results, Mineral Resources and Mineral Reserves in the United Kingdom, Ireland and Europe. The Code has been adopted by the Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining (IoM3), the Geological Society of London (GSL), the European Federation of Geologists (EFG) and the Institute of Geologists of Ireland (IGI), and is therefore binding on their individual members.

Value.label: RF
Value.definition: Russian reserve guidelines.
Value.description: Russian reserve guidelines are in a state of transition from the system utilized within Soviet state companies to a new system more closely aligned with the needs of private industry.

Value.label: SPE/WPC/AAPG(PRMS)
Value.definition: Petroleum Resources Management System.
Value.description: In 2000, the Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE) jointly with the World Petroleum Council (WPC) and the American Association of Petroleum Geologists (AAPG) published a Reserve and Resource Classification to address the requirement for an international standard. The underlying Reserves Definitions were unchanged from those published by the SPE/WPC in 1997. Additionally, in 2001 the SPE/WPC/AAPG jointly published Guidelines for the Evaluation of Petroleum Reserves and Resources as clarifications for the application of the 2001 and 1997 documents. Further clarification was provided in the Glossary of 2005, in particular by the definition of the term commercial, and thereby reserves.

Value.label: UNFC1997
Value.definition: United Nations Framework Classification (1997).
Value.description: The classification is based on three key attributes:
<ul>
• Economic (E)
• Field Project Status/Feasibility (F)
• Geological (G)

Value.label: UNFC2004
Value.definition: United Nations Framework Classification (2004).
Value.description: The classification is based on three key attributes:
<ul>
• Economic (E)
• Field Project Status/Feasibility (F)
• Geological (G)

Value.label: UNFC2009
Value.definition: United Nations Framework Classification (2009).
Value.description: The classification is based on three key attributes:
<ul>
• Economic (E)
• Field Project Status/Feasibility (F)
• Geological (G)

Value.label: USGS
Value.definition: United States Geological Survey.
Value.description: The USGS classification is based on two parameters whereby resources are classified by feasibility of economic recovery and degree of geologic certainty.

Value.label: cultivated
Value.definition: Species is cultivated, not occurring in the wild.

Value.label: extinct
Value.definition: Species has been extincted.

Value.label: introduced established
Value.definition: Species has been introduced and is reproducing with stable populations.

Value.label: introduced impermanent
Value.definition: Species has been introduced, but has no stable, reproducing populations.

Value.label: native
Value.definition: Species is occuring natively.

Value.label: naturally impermanent
Value.definition: Species is naturally introduced (by natural migration), but has no stable, reproducing populations.

Value.label: probably extinct
Value.definition: Species has not been observed by recent surveys, but no positive proof of extinction is possible.

Value.label: re-introduced or translocated
Value.definition: An extinct population of formerly native species has been re-introduced as a nature conservation measure.

Value.label: archipelagic
Value.definition: The baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the straight baseline joining the outermost points of the outermost islands and drying reefs of the archipelago.
Value.description: SOURCE Article 47 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label: normal
Value.definition: The normal baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the low-water line along the coast as marked on large-scale charts officially recognized by the coastal State.
Value.description: SOURCE Article 5 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label:
straight
--Definition-- The baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the straight baseline established by joining the appropriate points.
-- Description -- SOURCE Article 7 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
Value.definition: -- Name --
straight
--Definition--
The baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the straight baseline established by joining the appropriate points.
Value.description: SOURCE Article 7 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
