Value.label: female
Value.definition: A person or group of persons of female gender.

Value.label: male
Value.definition: A person or group of persons of male gender.

Value.label: unknown
Value.definition: A person or group of persons of unknown gender.

Value.label: congruent
Value.definition: This value expresses that the local type is conceptually the same as its related Pan-European type.

Value.label: excludes
Value.definition: This value expresses that the Pan-European habitat type is conceptually no subtype of its related local type.

Value.label: included in
Value.definition: This value expresses that the local type is conceptually a subtype of its related Pan-European type.

Value.label: includes
Value.definition: This value expresses that the Pan-European habitat type is conceptually a subtype of its related local type.

Value.label: overlaps
Value.definition: This value expresses that between the local and its related Pan-European type there is a certain overlap according to their definition and that differs from the other values of this list.

Value.label: equinoctialSpringLowWater
Value.definition: The level of low water springs near the time of an equinox.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: higherHighWater
Value.definition: The highest of the high waters (or single high water) of any specified tidal day due to the declination A1 effects of the moon and sun.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: higherHighWaterLargeTide
Value.definition: The average of the highest high waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: highestAstronomicalTide
Value.definition: The highest tidal level, which can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: highestHighWater
Value.definition: The highest water level observed at a location.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: highWater
Value.definition: The highest level reached at a location by the water surface in one tidal cycle.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE When used on inland waters it is generally defined as a level that the daily mean water level exceeds less than 5 percent of the time.

Value.label: highWaterSprings
Value.definition: An arbitrary level, approximating that of mean high water springs.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: indianSpringHighWater
Value.definition: A tidal surface datum approximating the level of the mean of the higher high water at spring tides.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE This tidal datum approximates the highest water level observed at a location and is usually above that of the higher high water at spring tides.

Value.label: indianSpringLowWater
Value.definition: A tidal surface datum approximating the level of the mean of the lower low water at spring tides.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE This tidal datum approximates the lowest water level observed at a location and is usually below that of the lower low water at spring tides.

Value.label: localDatum
Value.definition: An arbitrary datum defined by an authority of a local harbour, from which levels and tidal heights are measured by that authority.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: lowerLowWater
Value.definition: The lowest of the low waters (or single low water) of any specified tidal day due to the declination A1 effects of the moon and sun.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: lowerLowWaterLargeTide
Value.definition: The average of the lowest low waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: lowestAstronomicalTide
Value.definition: The lowest tide level that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: lowestLowWater
Value.definition: An arbitrary level conforming to the lowest tide observed at a location, or somewhat lower.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: lowestLowWaterSprings
Value.definition: An arbitrary level conforming to the lowest water level observed at a location at spring tides during a period shorter than 19 years.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: lowWater
Value.definition: An approximation of mean low water adopted as the reference level for a limited region, irrespective of better determinations later.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

NOTE Used mostly in harbour and river engineering. Used in inland waters. It is generally defined as a level which the daily mean water level would fall below less than 5 percent of the time and by no more than 0.2 metres during the navigation season. A single level surface is usually chosen as the low water datum for a whole lake. On a river, low water datum is a sloping surface, which approximates the surface of the river at a low state.

Value.label: lowWaterDatum
Value.definition: An approximation of mean low water that has been adopted as a standard reference for a limited area.
Value.description: SOURCE [Based on DFDD].
NOTE 1 It is retained for an indefinite period regardless of the fact that it may differ slightly from a better determination of mean low water from a subsequent series of observations.
NOTE 2 Used primarily for river and harbor engineering purposes.

Value.label: lowWaterSprings
Value.definition: A level approximating that of mean low water springs.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanHigherHighWater
Value.definition: The average height of higher high waters at a location over a 19-year period.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanHigherHighWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of higher high water at spring tides at a location.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanHigherLowWater
Value.definition: The average of the higher low water height of each tidal day observed over a National Tidal Datum Epoch.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE For stations with shorter series, comparison of simultaneous observations with a control tide station is made in order to derive the equivalent datum of the National Tidal Datum Epoch.

Value.label: meanHighWater
Value.definition: The average height of all high waters at a location over a 19-year period.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanHighWaterNeaps
Value.definition: The average height of the high waters of the neap tide.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanHighWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of the high waters of spring tides.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanLowerHighWater
Value.definition: The average of the lower high water height of each tidal day observed over a National Tidal Datum Epoch.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE For stations with shorter series, comparison of simultaneous observations with a control tide station is made in order to derive the equivalent datum of the National Tidal Datum Epoch.

Value.label: meanLowerLowWater
Value.definition: The average height of the lower low waters at a location over a 19-year period.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanLowerLowWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of lower low water at spring tides at a location.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanLowWater
Value.definition: The average height of all low waters at a location over a 19-year period.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanLowWaterNeaps
Value.definition: The average height of the low waters of the neap tide.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanLowWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of the low waters of spring tides.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanSeaLevel
Value.definition: The average height of the sea at a tide station measured from a fixed predetermined reference level.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE Usually determined from hourly height readings, for all stages of the tide, over a 19-year period.

Value.label: meanTideLevel
Value.definition: The arithmetic mean of mean high water and mean low water.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: meanWaterLevel
Value.definition: The average of all hourly water levels over the available period of record.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: nearlyHighestHighWater
Value.definition: An arbitrary level approximating the highest water level observed at a location, usually equivalent to the high water springs.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: nearlyLowestLowWater
Value.definition: A level approximating the lowest water level observed at a location, usually equivalent to Indian spring low water.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: tropicHigherHighWater
Value.definition: The highest of the high waters (or single high water) of the tides occurring semimonthly when the effect of the Moon's maximum declination is greatest.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE At these times there is a tendency for an increase in the diurnal range.

Value.label: tropicLowerLowWater
Value.definition: The lowest of the low waters (or single low water) of the tides occurring semimonthly when the effect of the Moon's maximum declination is greatest.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].
NOTE At these times there is a tendency for an increase in the diurnal range.

Value.label: LL
Value.definition: Lateral line.
Value.description: A lateral line is a small-diameter pipe that runs from the main line to the customer premises. LateralLine is a concrete class. The types of lateral lines are Combination, Commercial, Domestic, Fire, HydrantLateral, Industrial, and Irrigation.

Value.label: LL_Commercial
Value.definition: Commercial lateral line.
Value.description: Lateral line that transport water to commercial facilities.

Value.label: LL_Domestic
Value.definition: Domestic lateral line.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports water to domestic users.

Value.label: LL_Fire
Value.definition: Fire lateral line.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports water for the purposes of distinguishing fire.

Value.label: LL_HydrantLaterals
Value.definition: Hydrant laterals.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports water to the hydrants.

Value.label: LL_Industrial
Value.definition: Industrial lateral line.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports water to the industrial facilities.

Value.label: LL_Irrigation
Value.definition: Irrigation lateral line.
Value.description: Lateral line that transports water for the irrigation purposes.

Value.label: ML
Value.definition: Main line.
Value.description: A main line is a large-diameter pipe that carries water from the source through the network.

Value.label: ML_GM
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main.
Value.description: A gravity main is a type of main line that is unpressurized and relies on gravity to move the water through the main.
NOTE For the water distribution model, the types of gravity mains are Carrier, InlineStorage, and TransportPipe.

Value.label: ML_GM_Carrier
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's carrier.
Value.description: A carrier pipe is an inner pipe, or a hollow cylindrical tube contained inside an outer sheath. Responsible for carrying fluids, the carrier pipe runs through an outer, insulated casing that acts as a containment system that protects against spills.

Value.label: ML_GM_InLineStorage
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's in-line storage.

Value.label: ML_GM_TransportPipe
Value.definition: Main line's gravity main's transport pipe.

Value.label: ML_PM
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main.
Value.description: A pressurized main is a type of main line that is pressurized.

There are numerous types of PressurizedMains in the water distribution model; they include AirRelease, BlowOff, Bypass, ChemicalInjection, DistributionMain, Interconnect, PipeBridge, SamplingStation, and TransmissionMain.

Value.label: ML_PM_AirRelease
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's air release.

Value.label: ML_PM_BlowOff
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's blow off.

Value.label: ML_PM_Bypass
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's bypass.

Value.label: ML_PM_ChemicalInjection
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's chemical injection.

Value.label: ML_PM_DistributionMain
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's distribution main.

Value.label: ML_PM_Interconnect
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's interconnect.

Value.label: ML_PM_PipeBridge
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's pipe bridge.

Value.label: ML_PM_SamplingStation
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's sampling station.

Value.label: ML_PM_TransmissionMain
Value.definition: Main line's pressurized main's transmission main.

Value.label: aqueduct
Value.definition: A pipe or artificial channel that is designed to transport water from a remote source, usually by gravity, for freshwater supply, agricultural, and/or industrial use.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: bridge
Value.definition: A structure that connects two locations and provides for the passage of a transportation route over a terrain obstacle.
Value.description: SOURCE [Based on DFDD].
EXAMPLE 1 (Transportation route) A road or a railway.
EXAMPLE 2 (Terrain obstacle) A waterbody, a gully, and/or a road.

Value.label: culvert
Value.definition: An enclosed channel for carrying a watercourse under a route.
Value.description: SOURCE [Based on DFDD].
EXAMPLE 1 (Watercourse carried in an enclosed channel) A stream, a sewer, or a drain.
EXAMPLE 2 (Route over a culvert) A road, a railway, or an embankment.

Value.label: siphon
Value.definition: A pipe used for conveying liquid from one level to a lower level, using the liquid pressure differential to force a column of the liquid up to a higher level before it falls to the outlet.
Value.description: SOURCE [DFDD].

Value.label: contingentResources
Value.definition: Contingent resources are those quantities of energy resources estimated, as of a given date, to be potentially recoverable from known accumulations or deposits using established technology or technology under development. For coal organisations this category is often referred to as reserves.
Value.description: These quantities are not (yet) commercial. Maturing of the project to produce this quantity, or technical abilities or economic factors may convert these contingent resources into reserves.

Value.label: provenReserves
Value.definition: The estimated remaining quantities of a resource anticipated to be economically producible, as of a given date, by the application of development projects to known accumulations or deposits.
Value.description: Proven reserves are that part of the reserves for which the presence is 90 % certain.

Value.label: resourcesInitiallyInPlace
Value.definition: The total amount of a resource initially present in an accumulation or deposit.
Value.description: Hydrocarbons initially in place (HCIIP, GIIP, or STOOIP for Hydrocarbon, gas or oil respectively) is the quantity estimated to be initially present in an accumulation or deposit.

Value.label: P_OH_Single
Value.definition: Single phase primary overhead.

Value.label: P_OH_Three
Value.definition: Three phase primary overhead.

Value.label: P_OH_Two
Value.definition: Two phase primary overhead.

Value.label: P_UG_Single
Value.definition: Single phase primary underground.

Value.label: P_UG_Three
Value.definition: Three phase primary underground.

Value.label: S_OH_Single
Value.definition: Single phase secondary overhead.

Value.label: S_OH_Three
Value.definition: Three phase secondary overhead.

Value.label: S_UG_Single
Value.definition: Single phase secondary underground.

Value.label: S_UG_Three
Value.definition: Three phase secondary underground.

Value.label: streetLightConductor
Value.definition: Street light conductor.

Value.label: other
Value.definition: Other.
